to make ineffective: bē acārēnēt (sc. your work) with the explanation akartārēh-ic ō šmāh dahēt he will create ineffectiveness for you, he will make your work inefficacious 452. -- Den. of a-cār, v. cār. V. s. v. axuāyišnēh.
Ps.: v. haciš.

, with encl. ʾDYN-m = adak-im, ʾDYN-š = adak-iš etc. (ʾDYN-n = adak-in HajB: 5, v. -n); ʾDYN-c = adak-ic, then, by then, at that moment; in that case, this being so: 1. at the beginning of a sentence 285. 2925 sq. 37-- 61 passim, etc.; u ~ 399. 5421; u ~ -ic 3724; -- placed after the first w. of a sentence: api-š ~ 417.8; 5022; 4118; v. also below. -- 2. ~ ka at the time when 3615. 4117. 4415. -- 3. introducing the apodosis a) after hakar HajB: 9-10; 191-6 and passim; b) after ka HajB: 5; 185-10 and passim; ~ ka ..., xuarrah ~ ... at the time when ..., then the xuarrah 3615-16; -- c) after other clauses: tāi ... rasāt, ~ ... 4125-26; cē hān hōm dīt ... ~ -iš 4024-25; pat ēt kū ..., vēhān ~ -ic 5525-26; hān katārcihē kē hac dēn ākāh, ~ 6716; har martōm kē ..., ~ -iš 909; ō kē ..., ~ -iš ... 9019. -- 4. taking up the thread of a narrative after a lengthy qualification: pas hac matan i ... ~ -išān 4018-19; 807-8; 871-2. -- OP adakīy; [Page9-b] MPrs ʾyg = ēg < *ayag; Paz. aig, ag; aigin, agin: thus not only FrP 25, but also Mx and ŠGV, probably the petrifaction of ʾDYN-n HajB: 5 (v. above) with the obsolete encl. pron. -n. -- HajA: 10 ʾdyn: v. adyān.

painless, unafflicted 774. -- V. dart.

Prth, then, this being so HajA: 10. -- MPrth ʾdyʾn (S, A--H III); to be distinguished from SW ʾDYN, v. adak.

the quality of not passing away, continuance, continued existence (of the family) 5920. -- Av. (1554) pasca frasaxtahe mašyehe ‘after mankind has come to an end’, Vd. 1928, is rendered in Phl. by pas hac frāc-sacišnēh i martōmān, v. sacišnēh.

learning, teaching 6713. 8423; bun u [BʾW =] āfrās original text and teaching (= doctrine based on the bun) 1119. -- NW form; MPrs ʾʾfrʾh, ʾfrʾh, ʾprʾh ‘teaching, doctrine’ (S, BBB); Paz. veh-āfrāh ‘of good learning, well informed in the good Religion’, Skr. v. uttama-hita-dāyaka (Aog.). Cf Av. (999) ā-fras-. -- FrP 30 (31) BʾW bg. bd. ʾplʾs ʾplʾh, that is: BʾW: bag (bay) āfrās (āfrāh), which means: “the ideogr. BʾW signifies bag āfrās = [SW form] bay āfrāh”. BʾW, wholly coinciding in writing with bwn = bun, is BĀʾŪ, st. abs. of Syr. BĀʾŪT6Ā ‘petition, rogation’, the probable sense of the Ir. equivalent being ‘petition to the King or a royal person’. The lemma is thus given in Cod. S_1, but mutilated or corrupted in the other MSS; unrecognizable in Junker's ed. (ch. 31).

benediction, praise, blessing 773. 12818; ~ kartan to praise, to glorify, to utter benediction P 1:10-11. F: 5. 12819. 116. 1511; to bless 9427; to perform an invocation P 2:5. -- dahmān ~: v. dahmān. -- Av. (331) āfrīvana-; MPrth ʾfrywn; MPrs ʾfryn, ʾpryn (S, A--H II); NP āf(i)rīn. Cf the next ws.
(heavenly) created 6218, from [Page10-b]

(1017) ā-²frāy-, pres. ā-frīnā-, MPrth ʾfrydn ʾfryn- (v. also Sogd. 1724); MPrs ʾprydn, ʾpwr- or ʾfwr- (S, A--H II) ‘to praise, to bless, to worship’, cf s. v. appurišn. Another etymology by Bailey, BSOS VI, 1931, 587.
who has not his (proper) place, displaced, ejected 2626. -- V. gāh.

speechlessness, of dumb animals 119.

n. pr. 11013. -- Av. (49) Aγraē-raθa- ‘whose car drives at the head (of the fighters)’, a brother of Frāsyāk (q. v.); son of Pašang, v. BdA p. 1975. 23012 [ʾklyltˡ] = BdJ 6820. 794 [Paz. Aγririθi, Agrerad].
“not catching”, not involving liability or responsibility 651. -- V. griftār and griftārōmand.
undoubted, indisputable 8024. -- Paz. agumą. V. gumān and apē-gumān.
thus, then 3312. -- Av. (62 sqq.) aθā¤.
pres., to draw up (water): imp. pl. āhanjēt 1425. -- MPrs pt, ʾhxt, pres. ʾhynz-, Verbum 198; NP āhixtan āhanj-. Alternates in the same context with the simplex vb. hixtan hanj- (q. v.).
now 524; ~ ... nē not yet 727. -- MPrs ʾhnwn ‘now’, ʾhnwnc ny ‘not yet’ (S); NP hanūz.

1. holy, of the gods 5912; nar i ~ Dahmān Āfrīn 9210; Srōš ~, v. Srōš-ahlāi; epithet of religious authorities: ~ Zartuxšt 4212. 4427. 4621. 5810. 5915. 602. 1071; ~ Tōsar 11118. -- 2. righteous, pious: mart i ~ 3915. 826. 831; ~ nar u nārīk 7412; comp. ~ -tar 6420; [Page11-a] subst. the pious, righteous man 6516. 73224; pl. cas. obl. ~ -ān: ~ -ān martān zanān 5312; ~ -ān alone 6321. 7322. 8825. 10121. -- 3. blessed, of those in Paradise 8624; subst. pl. cas. obl. ~ -ān the blessed 8718. -- Borrowed from Av. (246 sqq.) ašā¤van-, nom. ašavā¤; MPrthPrs (Zoroastrian term) ʾhlw, pl. ʾhlwʾn (A--H II); as to the correspondence -š-: -hl- v. s. v. Mahlāh; Paz. ašō, pl. ašōą. V. ahlav-dāt, ahlāi, ahlāyēh. The genuine WIr form is OP artāvan ‘blessed’, whence MPrth ʾrdʾw ‘righteous, veracious’, also borrowed in MPrs (A--H II); v. further artāk.
a th. given to fulfil righteousness or piety; charity 9214-15. -- Paz. ašōdād6, Skr. v. puṇyadāna. In modern Parsism ‘the fees to the priests’, Modi, Ceremonies 407, 441-442.
= ahlav, v. s. v. Srōš. -- SW development of *ahlāv < Av. nom. sg. *ašāvā of ašāvant-, v. s. v. ahlav and cf artāk.
righteousness, piety 4523. 55-59 passim. 6620.23 etc. -- Paz. ašōī, Skr v. subhakti.
not similar (ō to) 812. -- V. homānāk.
immortal 782. 1049. -- Paz. axōš, V. hōš.

pt. = pret. pass. *āhōyēnīt [ʾhwkynytˡ !] *to insist on (pat) 383. -- Meaning approximately clear; reading hypothetical. I take it as the caus. *āyōdēn- of OP yaud- ‘to be in commotion’, Av. (1231 sq.) yaoz-, v. s. v. āyōz. This *āyōdēn- having developed into *āyōyēn- in SW, the first -y- was dropped and -h- inserted to fill the hiatus, according to the common rule; -k- is only graphic, as often after a w to assure its reading as -ō- -- if -k- is not simply (by no means uncommon) the defective form of the old letter d (cf the Ps.): *ʾhwdyn-. -- Commonly the spelling ʾhwkynytnˡ stands [Page11-b] for āhōkēnītan ‘to defile, to soil, to stain’, den. of āhōk, Paz. āhō, NP āhū ‘fault, defect, stain’, v. Zsprm ch. III, heading, Av. s. v. (345) āhita- and (346) āhiti-.

pres., to raise, to lift up, to lead upwards; pres. pass. 3d p. sg. ahrāmiyēt [ʾhlʾmy_dytˡ]: fratom gām pat humat ... apar ~ at the first step he is lead up to (the stage called) Good Thought 7326-27, but Paz. ārāmed6, Skr. v. niveśayati (West: ‘he rests the first footstep on Humat’). -- Ps. pret. ʾhlʾpty, pres. ʾhlʾm-, pt. ʾhlwpty ‘elevated’; MPrs ʾhrʾptn, ʾhrʾm-; MPrth pt. ʾhrʾmʾd; Paz. aharām-²išni, Skr. v. ākarṣana, aharāmihed6, Skr. v. kṛṣyate ŠGV XVI, 22. 26, treating of Manichean theology. Etymological attempts HP II, 5; Verbum 190; Ghilain 73; Ps. Gloss. As to -m-: -ft- cf ayinaftan, hanžaftan. Cf also āxrām-.
heretic, apostate 10711. -- Borrowed from Av. (257) ašəmaoγa-; Paz. āšmōg. As to -š-: -hr- cf s. v. Mahlāh and ahlav.
heresy, apostasy 8220. 10125. 10922.23.
4315. 5315. 581: read hārēftan [hʾlyptnˡ], q. v.

32-34. 62-63. 71 etc. passim. -- Av. (104 sq.) angra- mainyu-, aŋra- mainyu- (angra-, aŋra- < *ahra-); MPrthPrs ʾhrmyn; Arm. lw. Ahrmn; Paz. Āharman; NP Āharman, Ahraman, Ahriman. Cf Bailey, BSOS VII, 1934, 295 sq.

paramount chief, overlord, borrowed from Av. (281 sq.) ahū-, in the combination ahū-ca ratuš-ca overlord and chief judge, transposed into Phl ahū u rat (q. v.), whence the abstr. noun [Page12-a]
the state of being overlord and chief judge (of the material beings), of Zartuxšt 5520. -- ahū also in yaθā-²ahū-vairyō (q. v.)

hostile onslaught, destruction, the destructive power (almost personified) 5521. 7020. -- Paz. aibigad6, Skr. v. vināśa (Mx), pratipakṣa (ŠGV). Avestan w., but not attested in this sense: Av. (88) aiwi.gati- ‘commencement’.
adj. of the preceding w.: ~ sar the beginning of the Onslaught (in the cosmogony) 393. -- V. also an-aibigatīk.
n. pr. 473. -- BdA p. 2309 ʾylk = Ērak.

or, passim; also in disjunctive interrogation, e. g. 627-9. -- MPrs ʾyʾb; Paz. ayå; NP yā; < OIr. *ada-vā-pi: Av. (55) adā, aδa ‘then’, OP ada- id., + OIrSkr vā ‘or’ + -pi, v. -p.

rites, customs 818; cas. obl. ~ -ē [+ 1] nāmak 12119, the Sassanian code of courteous manners and conduct, NP āīn-nāmah, often referred to by Muslim authors. -- < OIr *abi-dayana- from *dāy- (v. dītan), whence NW-Prth ab-²dēn, but SW-Prs *aibidēn > *aiviyēn > āivēn. -- KZŠPrth 1. 19 ʾbdyn = Prs 1. 24 ʾdwyn, Gr. v. ; Ps. ʾdwyny translating Syr. nāmōsā = the Mosaic Law; MPrth ʾbdyn ‘habit, custom’ (Henning, TPhS 1944, 110-112); Arm. lw. aurēn-kʾ ‘institution, the Law; the Eucharist’; Syr. lw. b-ab6dēn ‘similar to’, cf also hāmōdēn; Paz. NP āīn, Skr. v. ācāra; Arab. lw. ʾāʾīn. V. Markwart, UJ VII, 1927, 89-121; Junker, WuS XII, 1919, 150. [Page12-b]

kind, sort, species, genus 423. 3917. 7611. 8023. 9417-20. 1083.10; nature 10014; -- manner: pat hān ~, pat ēn ~ in this, in such a manner; being in such a state; thus: 1120-21. 3416. 8519; the thing (event, situation) being so, connected with dītan 21. 322. 91727. 11614. 123. 1216; with āšnūtan 814, -- cē ~ 4813, pat cē ~ 762021. 788 how ?; pat ciš-ic ~ mā 703, pat hēc ~ ... nē 792-3 in no way, by no means; pat hān ~ ka griyēt so that he is weeping 1117; -- pat ~ i xuaršēt like the sun 4412; pat šusr ~ something like a sperm 9517; pat ōzanišn ~ by (means of) killing 10320; har 2 ~ in both respects 1106. -- MPrs ʾywyng (S, A--H II), ʾʾyng (List 80); Paz. āina, ŠGV āinaa, Skr. v. prakāra, ŠGV also vidhā, rīti. [MPrth ʾʾdyng, List 79, NP āī¤nah ‘mirror’ seems to go back to *ā-²dayana-]. -- Note: -- NP ādīnah ‘Friday’, for Islamic (yaumu-)l-jumʾa, cannot be etymologically connected with āivēnak, as Markwart has it (v. above s. v. āivēn); it probably goes back to MIr *atēnak < OIr *ati-ayana- (OP ati-ay- ‘to go along’), cf MPrs ʾdyn ‘entrance’ (S, A--H II), with secondary lengthening of the initial a-: *āδēnaγ ‘congregation’. -- V. also ham-āivēnak.

Prth if, in unfulfilled condition, construed with past pt. + Prth. opt. of h- (v. I, p. 175) both in protasis and in apodosis: ak šīty *dišt (ḤWY-ndy =) ahēndē ō bē ārak ākasī būt ahēndē if a cairn had been built it would have been visible from the outside HajA: 9. -- MPrth ʾg; < *hak < Av. (1742) hakat6 ‘at once, at the same time’, cf hakar.

aware, knowing 396. 574. 1082; ~ kartan to inform 1012. 1123; kē hac dēn ~ he who is enlightened by Religion 6716; subst. pl. cas. obl. kam ~ -ān the ignorant, the witless 11022. -- MPrs ʾgʾ (S); Paz. NP āgāh. Arm. lw. akah, certainly from Prth, proves that -s in ʾkʾs is spurious, and only the inverse spelling [Page13-a] of -h; thus it cannot be connected with ākas (q. v.), which also differs in meaning. From OIr *ā-kāθa-, derived through the suff. -θa- (OInd -tha-) from *kā-, Skr cāyati ‘to notice, to be aware’ (v. s. v. cašm-kāi). As ws. formed by the suff. -tha- are abstracts we have to explain *ā-kāθa- as ‘being with information, having good information’. cf Skr ā-manas- ‘being of favorable mind’. As to the spelling, cf pʾtkʾsy ‘renowned’ NRjb, 1. 4, but in the parallel passage of SM, end of 1. 25 (quite clear !) pʾtkʾhy, < *pati-kāθa-. V. also nikāh, gukāi. -- Compounds: duš-²ākāh, visp-ākāh.

information, message 32. 72. 4613. 594; -- religious doctrine(s) and tradition(s) commonly accepted by the community (in contradistinction to pai-²tākēh, q. v.) 1095.23. 1117.15; ~ governing an inf.: the accepted doctrine (tradition) is that 11111.22-23. -- Paz. NP āgāhī; FrO VIII: vaēδim [Av. (1321) vaēδaya-]: ākāhēh. -- V. kār-ākāhēh, visp-ākāhēh.
to inform a p. of (hac) 1323-24. 4727.

boundlessness, endlessness, of Ohurmazd 637.26.
ineffective, powerless: ~ kar-²tan to incapacitate 4218-19. 10320-21; ~ būt mar u start 542.6.10. -- V. kār. Paz. agār; Skr. v. an-upakārin- (Mx), āgār, Skr. v. akṣama (ŠGV).
to incapacitate, to destroy 4213. -- Paz. āgārined6, Skr. v. vināśayati (ŠGV XII, 43).

pass. of the preceding vb.: Ahriman bē akārihēt A. will be incapacitated, powerless 7710-11. -- MPrs ʾgʾryyhyyd (Sogd. 1619). Paz. has [Page13-b] another vb.: āsārihed6 (Antiā0: āšārihed6). Skr. v. parikṣīyate with the explanation akṣamo bhavati.

Prth: ~ būtan to be, become visible HajA: 9. -- From Av. (459) ā-kas-; FrO VIII viduš: ʾks; MPrth ʾgs ‘apparent, visible’. The final -y is not the silent final -y abundantly written in Prs. inscriptions and in the Ps.; this is wanting in Prth (quite exeptionally written in šītē, vitāvanē, q. v.). Here -y is a real ending, whether -ē or -ī is not clear, found in some cases where a pred. adj. forms a unit with būtan: MPrs wnybwt ‘annihilated’, ʾstwybwdn ‘to be defeated’ (List 89, v. s. v. stōb), probably also han-²girtīkēh (q. v.) graphically confounded with the abstr. noun in -ēh. [May I venture the humble guess that -ī originated from the instrumental of a fem. adj. in -ī-: *-iyā > -ī].
infidelity 10919. -- From ak-dēn ‘one having a bad religion’: Av. (44 sq.) aka- ‘evil’, cf akōmandihā.
adv. without hatred, forgivingly, magnanimously 355. -- V. kēn.
helpless 2627. -- V. kōc.
in an evil manner, pitilessly, mercilessly 753. Paz. substitutes for it anaōmēdihā ‘hopelessly’. -- From akōmand ‘belonging to (the world of) Evil’, aka; v. ak-dēnēh.
a hug: kū-šān pat ~ frāc grift gl. 4315, v. s. v. *hārēftan and v. griftan. -- Text: ʾknyh, meaningless. NP āgōš, āγōš.
to hang, to suspend, pt. ākust 2027. 328. -- Ps. 1362 ʾkwsty; MPrs ʾʾgwst (S); MPrth abstr. ʾgwstgyft (S). [Page14-a]

the hardest of the metals, possibly steel 7812. -- Borrowed from Gr. ; MPrs ʾrmʾs ‘steel’ (List 80); Paz. almāst, Skr v. pāṇḍarasika, according to West pāṇḍara-sikṣya ‘yellow-white crystal’; NP almās ‘a diamond; a glass; sharp iron’. Bailey, ZP 134; Henning, BSOAS XII, 1947, 45.
eagle; with indef. art. ~ -ē [~ + 1] 925. -- MPrs ʾlwf (List 79); NP āluh, < OP *ardufya- < *ardifya-, Av. (354) ərəzifya-.

the independent form of the cas. obl. of the pers. pron. 1st p. sg. = encl. -m me (q. v.): opening a sentence 3322; introducing the apodosis after hakar 344; taking up the encl. -m after a lengthy digression 345; am introducing the main sentence after an interrogative clause 528, after an adverbial 342. -- Cf aš, at etc.

(mixed act. and pass. construction) 7621. 772; -- governed by a prep. 1222. 3918. 4327 etc.; -- for the cas. rect. pl., being the subj. of a vb. in pres. 1044. -- Av. The etymology commonly given of this vb.: ham-vac- (v. 1vaxš and vācišnēh, patvāxtan) is by no means formally or semantically as evident as alleged. Formally the analysis ham + mauk- > 1) hammōk or > 2) hąmōk > (h)āmōk would seem more satisfactory, and semantically the difficulties are not insurmountable: *mauk-, Skr muñcáti ‘to let loose’, ham-mauk- ‘to give out (knowledge) from oneself’ (Skr sam-²muc- ‘to shed tears’). Already in 1936 Bailey derived Sogd. mwck ‘teacher’ from *hamauk, v. Gershevitch, GrMSogd § 397.

Mackenzie, An early Jewish Persian argument (BSOAS XXXI, 1968, 249-269), L. l. 14 (p. 262): whny ʾwy dʾd dyh ‘and He is the lawgiver’ (hesitatingly combined with ʾny by M. p. 254); Utas, The Jewish-Persian fragment from Dandān-Uiliq, Or. I, the cas. rect. of the pron. of the 1st p. sg.: P 2:1. 7; 5319 (v. s. v. tō).24 5719. 734.15. 7518. 9916. 11210. -- Only SW: MPrs ʾn (S, A--H II), ʾny (Henning, Iranistik 90 n. 2), as against MPrth ʾz = az < Av. (225 sqq.) azəm. Identical with 1 1an(ē), the full expression being an man, anē man or man anē (v. above). Through omission of man the epithet an(ē) became a sort of “modesty pronoun” for ʾIʾ, like NP bandah. This usage can be traced fairly far back. Cf the words of Tissaphernes, Xen. Anab. II, 523: . Curiously enough, in Swedish slang en annan ‘another’ is often [Page17-a] heard as such a “modesty pronoun” = I. -- This pron. is, however, obsolete in BP. and the cas. obl. man (q. v.) is regularly used as the cas. rect. The Pazandists had lost all tradition regarding the equivalent of the ideogr., which they transliterate mechanically aomen (Mx, ŠGV), when occurring in the texts. It was omitted in most MSS of the FrP (wanting in Junker's text), but exists in Codd. P and S_1, though with misunderstood Ir. equivalents.

as a rule used together with an encl. pers. pron.: ʾpm: api-m, ʾpt: api-t, [Page19-b] ʾpš: api-š, ʾpmʾnˡ or (Ps.) ʾpmn: api-²mān, ʾptʾnˡ: api-tān, ʾpšʾnˡ or (Ps.) ʾpšn: api-šān: 1. and, introducing and coordinating sentences, e. g. andar-rōn andar šut api-š guft 1813-14; coordinating substantives if the second subst. is determined by an encl. pron., e. g. zanišn i Ahriman api-š višūtakān 8819; also preceded by u: u api-t 620, u api-š 7822, u api-šān 795, etc. -- 2. introducing the apodosis after ka 94. 1025. 5225-27. 5418; after cigōn 931-2; after an isolated w. having the character of a protasis: hāmōdēn api-š hān zan ... ayyāt būt all this [to supply: engaging his attention], the remembrance of that woman came upon him 1111-12; -- taking up the sentence again after a preceding digression: hān zan u hān fradand i-š ... api-mān nē ōzat 1212-13. -- Av. (82 sq.) aipi, OP apiy ‘moreover, further’, both encl. and often only emphasizing: OP dūraiy apiy (and other spellings) ‘very far’; surviving in MiIr -p(i), q. v. Along with it there must have existed a fully stressed form *ápi; id.-europ. *e4pi (Gr postp. , prep. ), whence the genuine Arm. eu ‘and’; it is the counterpart of Gr , Lat et (eti-am). This *ápi > MiIr ap, in the sense of ‘and’ and in the apodosis, is normally used in the Sassanian official language as the bearer of encl. pronouns beginning the sentence, but in fact occasionally occurs alone, as in the Ps. (several instances, v. Gloss.); PR 231314. 347. 404; PhlY 3111 (introducing the apodosis). Apparently it was counted among the archaisms which needed explanation, because it was included in the FrP (ch. 24). Paz. has preserved some remnants of the archaic form: awam = api-m ŠGV VII, 22, awamą = api-mān ibd. VI, 47. X, 28. 35; Paz. AV, ed. Antiā0, Pā0z.texts 35818; hawašą = api-²šān ŠGV V, 62, etc.; the Paz. forms regularly occurring may be shortened allegro forms of api-m etc., v. s. v. u. The equivalents of api-m etc. given by the FrP are wm, wt, wš, which seem to coincide [Page20-a] with the MPrs forms ʾwm etc., v. u. Ap- was certainly obsolete in the spoken language when the Manicheans created their own literary SW language, which was not based on the usage of the Sassanian chancelleries. Prth preserved the encl. form -p(i), but ap- only in combination with other particles: Arm. lw. apa ‘then’ and introducing the apodosis, < ap + ā (q. v.); MPrth ʾbʾw (A--H III) < *apāv < ap + ā + Av. (1305 sq.) vā. [The usual identification of ap- with OAramHebr ʾaf ‘also’ is cogently refuted by this material].
water 1416-26 and passim; pl. cas. obl. āpān [ʾpʾnˡ] 10915. -- Av. (325 sqq.) āp-, OP āpi-; MPrthPrs ʾb; Paz. āw, āv; NP āb. -- V. āp-cihrak, āp-sārān, āpīk.

MIr pren. and prev. 1. MIr apa- represents both OIr apa- ‘off, away, de-, ex-’ and upa- ‘on (to), at, ad-’. -- 2. api-, OIr ‘on, in, over’, replaced a) the synonymous upa- when this merged with apa, and b) (in SW) OIr abi- (Skr abhi-) which became irrecognizable through phonetical changes. 3. OIr apa-, early used in MIr as a neg. pren. ‘without’, later assumed an independent form apē. BP ʾp- for apa- and api-, MPrs ʾb-; sometimes ʾpy-, MPrs ʾby- for api-; Paz. awa- throughout for both, which evidences at least a vocal murmur after the consonant; NP, with syncope of this vowel, af- or av (au-), later only af- (traces of ba- < awa-). For apē-: BP ʾpy-, ʾpyd6, MPrs ʾby-; Paz. awē-, NP bē- (bī-). I transliterate BP ʾp- throughout apa-, except when api- is expressly written [ʾpy-, ʾby-]. -- In Prth abi- was preserved; Arm. lws. have apa- mostly for OIr apa-, less often for upa- (in a few ws. pa- < OIr upa-, borrowed before u > a-), apə- (ə not written) for api-, au- (ō-) for abi-; apa-, later api- < apē- ‘without’; MPrth ʾb for apa- and abi-, sometimes ʾby- for api-, regularly ʾby for apē-. , to destroy, to annihilate: aš hamāk dām i tō bē apasihēnīt hāh [ḤWHˡ-ʾh] (cond.) 3121-321; -t ... nē apēsihēnītan (it is not for thee to =) thou shalt not be able to destroy 468 (MS ʾpys-, v. below s. v. apasistan). -- Paz. awasihinīdan (Mx), MiIr caus. of apa-sih- < *apa-sid-, v. apasistan. Its pass. is

pres. bē nē apasihiyēt [ʾpsh_ydytˡ, written so as to look like ʾpshhytˡ] will not be consumed, emptied 9710. -- The MiIr pass. suff. pres. -ih(ēt, -ēnd, etc.) being always written -yhytˡ, -yhynd (etc.) in BP, the reading ʾpshhytˡ = *apasihihet must be rejected and the second h taken as the ligature of -yd- which occurs frequently (cf the spelling of miyān and niyāk). Thus the correct reading is apasihiyēt. The original form of the pass. suff. was actually -iy(ēt, -ēnd etc.), which developed into -ih(ēt etc.), -y- having been dropped and -h- inserted in the hiatus. The preservation of -iyēt in apasihiyēt is without doubt due to the distaste for having two successive syllables beginning with h. -- The [Page24-a] problem of the Prs pass. suff. was conclusively solved by Schaeder, UJ XV, 560-- 570; conjectural solution already in Verbum 210-212, where the MPrs examples are collected; the starting point of the explanation was furnished by the J-Prs forms dealt with by Salemann, Z. mittelpers. Passiv, Bull. de d'Ac. Imp. des sciences de St.-Petersbourg XIII, 1900, 269-276.

, apēsistan [ʾpysstnˡ] apa-sī¤h- [ʾpsh-, ʾpsyh-] or apēsīh- [ʾpy²syh-], to be destroyed, annihilated: bē apasīhēt will be annihilated, of Ahriman 644, of the wicked 1031 (in both passages ʾpshytˡ in the printed editions); -- bē apāyet apēsīhāt (subju. 3d p. sg.) vīs i Pourušāsp the manor of P. (must be =) is evidently going to be destroyed 4419; nē bē apēsistan <i> vīs i Pourušāsp rād not in order that the manor of P. might be destroyed 4421. My spellings apasīhāt, apasistan in Dk are to be corrected; the scribe of the Dk MS (now available in reproduction) constantly writes all forms of this vb. and its derivatives ʾpys-, keeping the two letters y and s distinct with a care not very common in Phl. writing (in 4419 he wrote by a slight slip of pen ʾpʾs- instead of ʾpys-). The form apēsīhāt 4419 is directly confirmed by MPrs ʾbysyhʾd (S). -- < apa- + Av. (1547) saēd-, pres. pass. *apa-sidyati > MiIr *apa-sīy-ēt > apa-sīhēt or apa-siyy-ēt > apa-siyēt > apasi¤hēt; Paz. awasihed6, awasihend; M Prth ʾbsyst ‘dried’, Ghilain 83. The form with -ē-: apēsīhēt etc. goes back to *apa-²hisidyati with pres. reduplication (cf Av. ava-hisiδyāt6 which is, however, perf. opt.). The active pres. ‘to destroy’ was *apa-²sind- > apa-sinn- (always spelt ʾpsyn-): apa-sinnēt, apa-sinnišn (Paz. awa-sīnašn); from this are formed the secondary infinitives apa-sinnītan (BdJ 159), apēsinnī-²tan (Mx 2771), apasinnistan (KnA 79). Bal sindaγ ‘to break’, Skr chid- (< Id.europ. *sk10hid-), pres. chinad-, chind- (Lat. [Page24-b] scindo). This act. is generally supplanted by the secondary caus. apasihēnītan from apa-sih-. -- Note: -- There is a synonymous vb. of uncertain origin which may have been influenced by the apa-sih- vbs.: Paz. awasāinīdan ŠGV XI41 = Phl *apa-sāyēnītan; ʾpsʾdšnˡ = apa-sāyišn Mx 1538 (wanting in Cod. K); ʾpysʾsynytnˡ = apēsāhēnītan (the second -s- inverse spelling of h) DkM 1759. 35115 (in the MS 13410. 27018), ʾpysʾhšnyh = apēsāhiš-²nēh ibd. 1809 (= MS 13816); to be derived from *apa-sū- *apa-sāy- ‘to rub away’, cf s. v. apa-sūtak ?

probably: treated with magic art, of a sword 2516. 2813. -- [Page25-a] Cf NP afsūn, ausūn ‘charm’, afsā ‘a wizard’, afsāyīdan ‘to subdue, esp. by magic’, undoubtedly to be connected with NP sūdan sāy-, farsūdan farsāy (< *fra-) ‘to rub’, the magic treatment consisting of some special rubbing or stroking of the sword (< *upa-sū-, v. apa-). However, the corresponding OInd. vb. śā- means ‘to sharpen, to whet’ (śita- ‘sharp’) a sense also attested in Ir: NP afsān, ausān ‘whetstone’; MPrs hswd = hassūd < *ham-sūt ‘whetted’ of a sword (Henning, BSOAS XII, 1947, 45), directly to be compared with OInd (RV) saṃ-śā- ‘to whet’; thus apa-sūtak could simply mean ‘sharpened, whetted’. The parallel epithet distak (q. v.) is not quite clear.

(virtual dat.), a) governing an inf., which is as a rule placed after: u api-t xuatāyēh i Ērān šahr vas sāl apāyet kartan and thou shalt exercise dominion over Iran for many years 620-21; 918-19. 1014 etc.; in this case preverbs to the inf. are drawn to apāyet; bē ~ pursītan 1310; bē ~ hištan 1313; kār-ē i apar nē ~ kartan 1048; apārīk ō [KN] ~ xuartan 9422; less often the inf. is placed before: ōzatan nē ~ 101719; pit u māt frazand i xuēš rād ēn and kār u kirpak ... bē āmōxtan ~ the parents shall teach 6522-23; 6519-20; 9113; the inf. sometimes has to be supplied: [Page26-a] urvar har cē nē ~ (sc. hōšītan) ā nē hōšēt 9612-13; 9810-11; -- apāyet būtan it is bound to happen, of predestination, explains jāyišn 221, brihēnišn 162; used itself as a nominal expression of Predestination: apāyet-būtan rād 1611; -- b) taking a v. n. as its complement: -šān ... gōšt xuarišnēh nē ~ it is not allowed for them to eat meat 10420-21; -- c) governing a subordinate clause introduced by kū 81. 11813-14, by ka 5622 (gl.); without an introductory particle, with the governed vb. in ind. or in subju.: ~ stāyē thou shalt profess 596; bē ~ apēsīhāt 4418-19, v. s. v. apa-²sistan. -- MPrs ʾbʾyd with inf. to consider a p. worthy, governing a subordinated clause without an introducing particle, 5318 in a very complicated passage 5317-21, which only seems possible to understand on the following suppositions: a) kū-t bahr hac man bē burt l. 19 is not a gloss, as I have marked it, but is governed by anāk tō bavat l. 17 ‘it shall be unhappy for thee that thou hast bereft ...’; b) the clause kē ... aržānīkēnīt hom l. 17-19 is loosely attached to tō l. 17; c) for MNW-t L<y> (MS very clearly MNWtl) read MNW t<w> L<Y> = kē tō man, tō man being the exact counterpart of LK ʾNH = tō an (v. 2an) 1. 19 and both signifying ‘thou and I’; d) YBLWN-m l. 18 and 20, and ḤWHˡ-m l. 19, are the 1st. p. pl. coinciding with the 1st p. sg.; e) there is a wordplay between ʾš = āš ‘food’ l. 18 and ʾš = aš (demonic) eye’ l. 20 (aš burtan ‘to have a vision’, v. ˡaš; bahr ‘ministry’, v. this w.). Text: anāk tō bavat, marak, kē t<ō> man fratom hac axu i astōmand andar Rāg u Nōtar hac bahr barišnēh āš barom frāc aržānīkēnīt hom, kū-t bahr hac man bē burt. nūn-ip tō an pat apar-barišnēh aš barom u ēt bavēt kū-t dušcašmihā pat an xānak nikēram i-t nēst ‘unhappy shall it be for thee, little scoundrel, (that thou) -- as thou and I first of all men in the material world between Rāg and Nōtar have been found worthy of earning food by performance of ministry -- that thou hast bereft me of the ministry. Now thou and I shall be enraptured in an ecstatic vision, and then it will happen that I shall see thee evil-minded in another house that is not thine’. The passage is the immediate continuation of the incident related in 537-15. Zsprm XII, 7 epitomizes 5316-21 as follows: dwlyslwb BRʾ ʾL zltwšt gwptˡ ʾYK cygwnt pltwm ḤWHˡ-m bʾhl wlwcyk BRʾ ʾpk6nd ḤWHˡ-m ZK tw ʾNH KRʾ [Page31-b] 2 ʾš MDM YDLWN-m ʾpt BRʾ mlcynym = Dūrēsrav bē ō Zartušt guft kū: cigōn-at fratom ham (cf 209 etc.) bahr u rōcīk bē apakand hom, an tō an (v. 1an and 2an) har 2 aš apar barom api-t bē marnjēnēm ʾD. said to Z.: because thou hast deprived me, as the first, of both ministry and food, we both, thou and I, shall be enraptured in an ecstatic vision, and then I shall annihilate thee’.

professing (a religious faith: pat) 6311. -- MPrs ʾʾstwʾn (A--H II, BBB); Paz. āstvą; NP ustuvān ‘firm, trustworthy’. From Av. (1594) ā + stav-, cf stāyītan. As to the spelling -wp- for -v- cf bwpʾy = bavāi 2723; from this [Page33-a] digraph the letter w of the Av. alphabet (I, 129) was created.

(215 sq.) astvant-.

the independent form of the cas. obl. 3d p. sg. = encl. -š (q. v.); always preceding the w. to which it belongs; used 1. anaphorically in the interior of a sentence after a part of the sentence which has been placed first for emphasis: andar hān Zartuxšt / aš hac miyān āp i hōmīkān burt // u pat ulēh Zartuxšt / aš hān i dašn paitištān hac O1šān rōtē burt 5615-17 (Markwart's reading, Cat. 114 n. 1, is a failure); ōi (pron.) mar / aš ō pasēh gāv apāc rānēnīt 485; -- not anaphorically: ōi (prep.) fravahr i Zartuxšt / aš (viz. the snake) zafar frāc zat 4012-13; purr-xuarrahēh i axu i astōmand / aš hac tan xuarrah from his (viz. Zartuxšt's) bodily splendour 377-8; -- taking up an encl. -š at the beginning of the sentence, after a part of the sentence which carries a lengthy attribute: api-š hamāk damīk i-š apar rāh būt / aš *pērāvanihīt kart 3316-17; -- after an adverbial phrase beginning the sentence: adak apar pat jamān / aš hanjamanēnīt mūtak 619 (where aš anticipates mūtak, cf. s. v. -š). -- 2. to introduce the apodosis (as api-š, adak-iš): after hakar 3121; after ka 327. 3318. 341. 565. 5717. 924. after a relative clause 3219. 9824. 10027-- 1012. -- Probably identical with MPrthPrs š, written as an independent w. with two dots above (another explanation of this š v. A--H III, Gloss s. v.; šʾ in a fragmentary context [S] is obscure). Cf am, at, atān, ašān.

food, victuals and drink 5318, v. s. v. aržānīkēnītan. -- NP āš ‘meat, soup, broth’; cannot be identified with [Page34-a] Skr āśa-; possibly contracted of *ā-yiša- from Av. (1281) yah- ‘to seethe, to boil’, pres. yaēša- with reduplication < Id. eur. *i‡e-i‡so- (from the same st. Gr ‘leaven’, yeast, etc.) ?

pl. of the pron. aš (v. 2aš) them, their: 1. adak Zartuxšt 3 hazangrōzim / ašān ... paitāk sahist ... 3824-26; 7 sāl pēš i hān gazān / ašān pus jūt 403. -- 2. introducing the apodosis after ka 3414. 9724, after a relative clause 1011015. -- Cf -šān.

: api-š ... frāc *ā¤šē-²hīt purr dōrak hān i asp pēm *took out, brought forth, put before (the guests) 532. -- Reading, original sense, and etymology are equally uncertain. The parallel text Zsprm XII, 2 has: šīr i asp ē yāmak pēš nihāt.

laziness, indolence 8416. -- Thus spelt, with a marked g, Mx Cod. K here and ch. 515; in the same ch. also ʾšygyʾn (possibly only a slip of pen for ʾšgydʾn) and ʾšgdʾnyh (no mark over g). These spellings represent respectively: ʾšgyhʾn a form ašgihān, ʾšgydʾn, ʾšgdʾn a form ašgiyān, exemplifying the common alternation of intervocalic -y-: -h-, cf s. v. apasihistan and doublets such as drāyītan: drāhītan, xuāhēt: xuāyišn, etc. The common BP spelling is ʾšghʾn, passim. However, the Paz. forms are aš(a)gā¤han, aš(a)gahān; MPrs ʾjgʾhʾnyy (Henning, GGA 1935, 14); NP ažgahān, ažgā¤n, ažhān (BQ) + ažgīn (Steingass). The forms with -gā- seem difficult to reconcile with aš-²gihān, ašgiyān. -- I do not insist on the etymology in HP II, 24.
, aškam [ʾškm], aškom [ʾškwm], also [KLSH 1013.18. 1111. 6513], belly, stomach, womb 320 etc. -- MPrs škmb (A--H II; Sogd. 3126); Paz. aškum (Mx), iškam (ŠGV); NP iškam, šikam.
n. pr., the ancestor of the Aškanian, or Arsacid, dynasty; Zēndān [Page34-b] i ~ the name of a town 11625-26. -- Markwart, Cat. 20, reads Ašakān.
patron. of the preceding name 10818. 11415.26. -- NP Aškā-²niyān; Arab. al-xaškānīya (read -x- instead of -ḥ-) and al-ašg3ānīya, Fihrist 32730.31.
n. pr. of a town in W. Iran 11712. -- Unknown, v. Cat. 105 sq.
the act of making manifest; pat ~ in a manifesting, detecting manner 6715.
well-known 782. -- MPrs ʾʾšnʾg ‘well versed in’ (A--H II); Paz. āšnā, Skr. v. prasiddha; as to the etymology cf s. v. šnāxtan.
the act of hearing; hearing 6627. 9415. 1116; hence

det. v. n. in compounds: pas hac ēn gōbišn ~ after having heard this speech 518, with the gl. ka šmāh ēn gōbišn āšnūt; pat hān gōbišn ~ 5110, with the gl. ka ōišān hān gōbišn āšnūt būt. -- Paz. šnavašni (ŠGV, Mx).

āšnav- to hear 211 etc.; 1283; with kū that 1515. 1823; apar āšnūt had heard, been told, informed 6116. -- OP (NRjb) ā-xšnav-, Benveniste, TPhS 1945, 47-50; MPrs ʾšnwdn (S), imp. ʾšnww (A--H II); MPrth ʾšnwdn (S), pres. ʾšnw- (A--H III); NP šunūdan, šinīdan, šinav-; Paz. cf the predecing w.
= ahlav, q. v.; pl. cas. obl. ~ -ān 1061. -- A learned w., taken over as a religious term from Av. ašava, nom. of ašavan-, v. s. v. ahlav.
confusion, tumult, sedition 381. 1081. -- MPrthPrs ʾʾšwb, ʾšwb (A--H [Page35-a] III; Verbum 184); cf MPrth. ʾšwb-gr ‘instigator to rebellion’, abstr ʾšwbgryft (S); NP āšōb. V. also āšuft-kārēh.
messenger, apostle 363. 579.11; ~ cas. rect. pl. 5823. -- Av. (260) ašta-.
mission 364; apostolate 5515.19. 562.
peace 5612.13. 6416. 666. 7818. 796. -- Av. (311) āxšti-; MPrs ʾʾšt; xw-²ʾšt-wrz ‘bringing about good peace’ (A--H II), xwʾštyh (S); NP āšt. V. also an-²āštēh.
scourge 9621. -- Av. (263) aštrā-.
subversion, upheaval 10819. -- From āšuftan āšōp-, v. āšōp and cf višuftan; MPrth ʾšyft (A--H III). Ghilain 95; Bailey, BSOS VI, 1930, 73.
the independent form of the cas. obl. of the pers. pron. 2nd p. sg., for encl. -t (q. v.): taking up tō after a relative clause 3314; cf am, aš.
pl. of the preceding w., for encl. -tān: taking up šmāh after a relative clause 451.
(Prth) [ʾtrw] fire, pl. cas. obl. ātarūn [ʾtrwn] ŠPrth: 2-3, v. ātur. -- The reading ʾtrwn (Ghirshman: ʾtryn) is confirmed by KZŠPrth 1. 19, where -wn is perfectly clear.

fire, in the ordinary sense 202 and passim; -- in the Zoroastrian creed and cult: personified as the son of Ohurmazd 311.12--35, passim; 586.20. 593; worshipped 353. 6620-22. 956, cf 1167; one of the basic elements of the creation 922. 942527. 982425. 12013; mān i ~ -ān firetemple 6620-22; ~ alone in this sense 11312; ~ (i) Varhrān (Vahrām), ~ i Karkōi: v. these ws. -- Borrowed from Av. (312 sqq.) ātar- (v. the next w.), sg. nom. ātarš; Paz. NP ātaš (-x- in ātaxš inorganic as in Zartuxšt; an attempt to explain it as purely graphical v. de Menasce, Feux p. 43). [Page35-b]

fire, referring to the old Iranian fire cult: ~ yazēt god Ātur 252; ~ farrōbā¤g, gušnasp u burzēn mihr the names of the three sacred fires connected with the three classes of the old Iranian society 118, explained 27-9; ~ farrōbāg, i -bag 924. 9511; ~ gušnasp 955; ~ burzēn mihr 9513; ~ -ān šāh the head of the sacred fires 1222-23. 131; -- sāl 58, ātury i Artaxšahr sāl 40, ātury Šāhpuhr i āturān šāh sāl 24 ŠPrs: 1-3 = sār 58, ātarō Artaxšahr sār 40, ātarō Šāhēpuhr ātarūn xšāh sār 24 ŠPrth: 1-3: ‘... of the year 58 (viz). the year 40 (of =) after the (enthronement) fire of Artax-²šahr, the year 24 (of =) after the (enthronement) fire of Šāhpuhr, the head of the fires’, which means the year 266 A. D., v. Christensen apud Ghirshman, Rev. des arts asiatiques X, 1936, 127-128 (the year 40 reckoned from the coronation of A. in the year 226, the year 24 reckoned from the coronation of Š. in the year 242, and the year 58 reckoned from what must have been the epochal year of Sassanid time-reckoning, viz. 208 A. D.). -- [~ the name of the 9th day of the month, also of the 9th month of the year; dadv (q. v.) pat ~ the name of the 8th day of the month: FrP 28.] -- Av. v. s. v. ātaxš; Prth ātarō (q. v.); MPrthPrs ʾdwr; Paz. ādur; NP āδar, ādar. As to the three sacred fires v. Christensen, Sass. 164-- 167; cf also de Menasce, Feux (1964); Mary Boyce, BSOAS XXXI, 1968, 52-- 68, 270-289.
n. pr. 11125. -- Paz. Ādarfarōbag; also the name of a sacred fire, v. above; v. farrōbag.
patron. of the preceding w. 1126.
n. pr. 1085. 10916. 11016. 11210. -- “Protected by the Fire”, v. pātan; Av. (318) n. pr. Ātərəpāta-.
the name of the province Adharbaijan and its capital 955. [Page36-a] 11713.18. -- KZŠPrth ʾtwrptkn, Gr. v. ; class. Gr ; derived from n. pr. Āturpāt.

setting fire to, igniting; an [ZK] šmāh hat ~ another shall set fire to you [O plants !] 951-2, with the gl. ka-š apar nihēnd ā frāc gīrāt when one puts [them, viz. the plants] on it (viz. the fire) it shall envelop [them]. -- V. sōxtan.
= Āspiyān (q. v.) 11627. -- Paz. Āθwyāną (Aog.). As to the spelling -ywʾ- for -iyā- cf s. v. āyiyān.

, pl. ~ -ihā [-yhʾ] time, age 57. 1313. 5523. 11014-15.18. -- < OIr. *abi-²gāma-, Av. (89) aiwi.gāma- ‘winter, year’; Prth Paik ʾbgʾm; MPrth ʾʾgʾm (S); PrsPaik, Ps. ʾwbʾm; MPrs ʾwʾm (S); Paz. has the NW form: ōgąm (Mx), ōγąm (ŠGV). Markwart, UJ VII 90; Junker, WuS XII, 151; Bailey, BSOS VI, 1930, 63; Barr, Ps. Gloss. s. v.
adj. of the preceding w.; subst. pl. cas. obl. ~ -ān those belonging to this age (of the world), homines huius saeculi 8824. -- Paz. substitutes ōgąmą, v. above.

1. adv. down here: (ka ...) ~ ō Satistūny āmat (as ...) he came down here to S., P 1:5. -- 2. used as an imp. ‘come here !’ with the pl. ~ -ēt [LPNHˡ-yt]: 1419. 2222 (v. s. v. druyist); frāc ō pēš ~ ! step forward ! 2818.20; -- also in the 1st p. pl. ā¤varēm let us go ...! 1920, where ʾwlym = ā¤varēm was misread as hwlym = xuarēm and the ideogr. of the latter: ʾŠTHn-ym, was substituted for it, v. s. v. *hōnēh. -- Av. (176) avarə, avarə1; MPrthPrs ʾwr, ʾʾwr-ṭ, pl. ʾwryd, ʾʾwryd; still common in modern NW dialects in various forms. Nyberg, Danielsson Vol., 1932, 237-261; Ghilain 47. Cf ōrandar, ōristar.

*procuring one's wealth from (hac) 6312.17; comp. ~ -tar 6717. -- Reading and meaning quite hypothetical; from ā + vart- (v. vaštan) ? Cf Av. (176 sq.) [Page36-b] a-varətā- ‘property’, whence a den. vb. *āvart- ‘to acquire property’ ?
(Prth) [ʾws] now HajA: 11. -- MPrth ʾwʾs (A--H III, MHC); Paštō ōs. Presumably a derivative of the dem. ava- (v. ō, ōi) and parallel to has (q. v.).

to seal, pt. = pret. pass. 3d p. sg. āvašt 1925; pt. āvašīt [ḤTYMWN-ytˡ] sealed up 11722; [pai-²tāmbarān (ʾwbštˡ =) āvašt the seal of the prophets, of Muhammad, = Arab xātamu l-nabīyīn, DkM 2916]. -- Reading according to Henning, BSOAS XI, 1946, 725 sq. FrP ch. 23 gives for the ideogr. the gl. ʾwbštnˡ (var. ʾwbstnˡ), to which Cod. U_5 adds the pres. forms 3d p. sg. ʾwbšytˡ = āvašēt, 1st p. pl. ʾwbʾšym = āvāšēm (or possibly ʾwbhšym = āvaxšēm); it should, however, be observed that the Paz. readings are throughout anbaš-, anbiš-, thus ʾnbš-, not ʾwbš-, so Bthl was fully excused in his reading and etymology (MirM II, 37-38), which Henning seems not quite to have understood (Bthl. translated it ‘festmachen’ but used this w. in a juridical sense: ‘to make a document valid before the law’ through applying one's seal on it, which is in fact not far from the truth, v. Nyberg, By-²zantion XXXVIII, 1968, 119-122).

miraculous, marvellous, wonderful 311. 3818. 4515. 5021. 1062.17; ~ sahistan impers. with the subj. in a virtual dat. (it seems wonderful, astonishing to a p. =) to wonder, to be surprised, astonished at (pat) 22. 322-23. 158-9. 9724-25. -- Av. (96) abda-, abdō.təma-; MPrth ʾbdyn (S, A--H III); Paz. awad, awad6. Cf Junker, WuS XII, 1929, 133 sq.
wonder, miracle(s) 36-61. passim; zāyišn ~ 4424, zāyišn i Zartuxšt ~ 4726 the wonderfulness of Z.'s birth, his miraculous birth; -- coll. wonderful things 1052.

(Prth) [ʾwpdštn] to give directions, to issue an order: pt. = pret. pass. 3d [Page37-a] p. sg. avdišt HajA: 10 (= Prs framāt Haj B: 11), followed by the relative clause MNW BNY-t (to one who built =) that it should be built. -- KZŠPrth 1. 16. 19 ʾwpdšt, pres. ʾwpdys-; MPrth ʾbdyšt, ʾbdys- ‘to show, to inform’, ʾbdys ‘instruction, injunction’ (A--H III, Ghilain 61); Av. (672 sq.) daēs-, avi- (aoi-) daēs- ‘to show, to prescribe’. It would be tempting to take the spelling ʾwpdšt as an archaism reflecting OIr *upa-dišta- (cf Skr upa-²diš-), but it seems safer to take -wp- as the NW digraphic notation of -v-, as against the SW digraph -wb-, v. s. v. āstavān. In itself ʾwpdšt, ʾbdyšt etc. can go back either to *abi-dišta- or to *upa-²dišta-.

last 4415. 469. 496.20; adv. in the end, finally, ultimately 726. 10119; pat ~ id. 698; cas. obl. pat avdomēh id. 7713. -- OIr *apa-tama-, borrowed in B.-Ar. ʾappet6om Ezr. 413; MPrs ʾbdwm, pd ʾbdwmyy (S); Paz. awadum, awadim.
not good 10512. -- V. vēh.

the act of blaming, disgracing a p.: vattarān ~ kartan to disgrace evil people 716, opp. vēhān pat pātdāšin (v. s. v. pat I: II) kartan to reward good people; -- [kē an-iškōhtar ? hān kē ~ i martōmān vattar sahēt kū niyāzōmandēh who is (the most notpoor =) the least affected by poverty ? he who considers being blamed by men worse than being needy PT 951-2; when a man makes his confession, hān kē pēš patīt bavēt (i. e. the priest-confessor) aš xūp niyōšišn, [MN-š for] api-š nē ~ [MN-š for] api-š rāz bē nē barišn, cē ka pat vinās i kart bē āvēnēt aivāp rāz bē barēt aš havand bavēt shall listen benevolently (to the man confessing his sin), and he shall not disgrace him, nor divulge his secret, for if he disgraces him for the sin he has committed, or divulges his secret, he becomes equal to him ŠnŠ 8: 9, p. 107, Cod. K 20 fol. 67 r.]. -- Paz. avīnešn [Page37-b] (Mx 1537; 716 an unexplained vb. ajīhašn), Skr. v. nindā; from OIr *ava-vaina- (v. dītan) ‘to look down on, to despise a p.’, whence, through syncope, *avvēn > āvēn- (or possibly, through haplology, avēn-), or, with contraction, ō-vēn- attested DkM 4761: ʾwwynytnˡ = ōvēnītan, opp. bur-²ž(ēn)ītan (Cod. K 43, fol. 179 v., adds here another dictum: hān i apoxšāyišn nē [ʾwwynšnˡ =] ōvēnišn u hān i ōvēnišn nē buržišn ‘he who is to be shown mercy shall not be disgraced, and he who is to be disgraced shall not be praised’). Henning paved the way for the correct understanding by pointing to the MPrth vb. ʾbwyn- ‘to blame’ < *apa-vaina- (Iranistik 99, n. 1), which is, however, only a synonym of, but not formally identical with, āvēn-. -- This vb. must thus be carefully distinguished from forms with a- privativum + vēn-: a-vēnišnēh DkM 1103 as opposed to vēnišn ‘the act of seeing’; Paz. avīnašnī 1. < -īk, Skr v. adṛśya, 2. < -ēh: adṛśyatva, ŠGV VIII, 28-34.
read [ʾwdlʾy =] udrāi (q. v.).

devastated: ~ kartan to devastate 1078. 1167. -- KZŠPrth ll. 5. 12 ʾwyrn, Prs l. 15 ʾwylʾn (+ BD-t ¶ krty, Gr. v. ); Arm. lw. aweran-kʾ ‘ruins, devastation’; Paz. avīrą; NP vīrān, bīrān, vairān. The spelling ʾpy- is possibly due to association with the pren. apē-, ‘without’, v. s. v. apa-. V. also Bthl, ZairWb 110, n. 1; Bailey, BSOAS XI, 1943, 2.
free from sin, sinless 3413. -- Paz. a-gunāh, v. vinās.

not gaining, not winning: l. of a p.: defeated 4215; ~ kartan to do away with 489; -- 2. of things: fruitless, wasted, lost 6814.20. 6922.27; -- [kē (for ka) xuāstak xuart i pitar kart u handōxt, i dūtakān yāft, avinn (ʾwbn) būt šut ... when the fortune has been consumed that his father made and [Page38-a] collected and the members of his family acquired -- (when it) is lost and gone PT 16613-15; -- common theological term expressing the nothingness of Ahriman and the evil powers, especially from an eschatological point of view: ~ -ēh i Ganāk mēnōi DkM 852, v. also ~ -būtēh; andar višuft-Ahrimanēh, ~ -druž<ēh>, apasihīt dēvēh u nēst-paitiyārakēh in a state where Ahriman has been destroyed, the drugs defeated, the devs annihilated, and there are no adversaries DD 798-9; den. vb. avinnītan [ʾwbynytnˡ]: opt. avinnēš DkM 83811; avinnītārēh DD 7514; avinnēnītan, pass. avinnihistan ibd. 7648; etc.]. -- Paz. avīn, Skr v. an-upakārin ‘doing no service, useless, fruitless’ (Mx), vikala ‘defective, impaired’ (ŠGV). FrP ch. 25 gives full evidence as to sense and etymology of this w.: ʾwbynˡ. ʾycn. LʾYTˡ.nystˡ. hcš. hcyš (var. hcš !, ʾzyš), Paz. ōbīn (K ōbin). ēzin (var. aizin, Arab letters ʾzyn, ʾyzn) rwīd6 nīst aziš (var. ajiš), the lemma being: ʾwbynˡ: ēcin (LʾYTˡ =) nēst haciš; commentary: -- 1. ēcin < *aiva-cina ‘even one thing’, with neg. ‘no one thing, nothing at all’: Av. (594) -cina encl. emphasizing part. in neg. sentences, (595) cina- ‘whoever’, (595, 762) dvācina ‘two men whoever they may be’, (24) aēvā-²cina in obscure context; 2. LʾYTˡ glossed by nēst, and ambiguous hcš elucidated; 3. the lemma says: ʾwbynˡ means: ‘no one thing comes from it, there is no gain from it’. The reading is almost self-evident: a-vinn < *a-vinda- from Av. (1318 sqq.) 2vaēd- ‘to find, to acquire, to share, to gain’, thus ‘not gaining’; also representing Av. (348) ə-vindan- ‘left without any share’ (of the food, of dogs Vd. 1328). As to the assimilation of -nd-²> -nn-, common in SW, cf MPrs bn = bann < band; BP apa-sinn- (v. s. v. apa-²sistan), nivinn- < ni-vind- (q. v.). -- This etymology was already given in HP II, and I maintain it firmly. The most unhappy idea of Geiger (WZKM XL, 107), taking ʾwbyn as an Aram. ideogr. and [Page38-b] reading ʾWBDN (common Syr and Mand ʾBDNʾ ‘perdition, ruin’) in spite of the clear indigenous tradition, was unfortunately embraced by Henning (GGA 1935, 14), and then passed into school doctrine (Iranistik 99 n. 1); it remains a failure.
abstr. of the preceding w.: waste, loss 420-21; the state of one defeated 638. -- As to formation cf MPrs hyʾrbwdyh ‘friendship’ (A--H II).
: read ā-vēnišn.
having no belief, unbeliever, pl. cas. obl. (used as cas. rect.) ~ -ān 978. -- V. virrōyistan, cf Paz. agrōišnihā (ŠGV; for agar-).

(Prth) to place, to set, is the probable reading of the Prth ideogr. ḤQʾYMW- = Prs ḤNḤTWN- (= nihā-²tan): pt. = pret. pass. 3d p. sg. ḤQʾYMW-t = avistāt HajA: 7, opt. 3d p. sg.: hyp ḤQʾYMW-d = hēp *avistē(d) HajA: 12, cf s. v. zām-. -- MPrth pt. ʾwystʾd = avis-²tād, subju. 2nd p. sg. ʾwystʾ = avistā ‘to place’ (A--H III), from Av. (1601 sq.) ava-stā-, Ghilain 90 sq.; cf ōstātan.

adv. 1. used instead of the prep. ō if it refers back to an encl. pron. in the beginning of the sentence: zahr i-š ~ frēstīt the poison that was sent to her 918; kū-t ... ~ nē rasēt lest ... shall come upon thee 688-9; api-š ... ~ barēt bring for him ! 748-9 = bē-š ~ barēt 767; puhr i-š ... ~ mat the punishment that has come upon him 7410; cigōn ka-šān ... ~ hilēnd as if one poured ... upon them 10120-21. -- 2. as a substitute for the prep. ō + the encl. pron. 3d p. sg. -š: 14.16. 41315. 727, etc. passim; taking up the rel. pron. 4226. 7213 v. s. v. kē. -- Ps. ʾwbšy; MPrs ʾwyš, from an OP adv. *abišā or *abišah derived from Av. (87 sq.) aibī, aiwi = OP abiy, as patiš (q. v.) from pati (cf also haciš: hac). I maintain my opinion expressed in HP II, 212; a [Page39-a] different opinion by B. Utas, OrSu XIV-- XV, 1965-1966, 118-129.
n. pr. 1821. -- Hebr ʾAb6rāhām, cf Arab Ibrāhīm; Paz. Abrā-²hīm (ŠGV).
splendour, magnificence 1219. -- < OIr *abi-ranga- v. rang; NP aurang, afrang. [On MPrth ʾbrng v. Henning, TPhS 1945, 154 n. 1].

āvar- [YḤYTYWN-], subju. 2nd p. sg. ~ -āi 2720, pt. = pret. pass. 3d p. sg. āvurt [YḤYTYWN-tˡ,ʾwwltˡ], opt. pass. 3d p. sg. āvurt hē [ḤWH-d] 218: to bring a th. to a p. (ō) 218 (aviš, q. v.). 610 (ō pēš i); 1526 (ō ēn giyāk to this place here); 769. 10916. 11310; ō ē giyāk ~ to put together, to compose 11920-21; to fetch down 4021; to inflict (a punishment) 93; to acquire (a name, renown) 2720; -- andar ~ to introduce 10317; -- apāc ~ to bring back, to restore (ō to) 514. 175. 10911, hac from (a state) 11215, hac ... ō from one state to another 1122-3; -- apar ~ to send forth, to emit 716; to assault 984-5. 10712; -- bē ~ to bring 207; to emit 3719; -- ō bērōn ~ to take away, to carry off 1011. 147; -- pat dīt ~ 42 v. dīt. -- Av. (938) ā-bar-; MPrthPrs pt. ʾʾwrd, pres. ʾʾwr-; Paz. āwardan, āwar-; NP āvurdan, āvardan āvar-(ār-); v. burtan.

āxēz- [ʾhyc-, KDMWN-] to stand up 1418. 3217. 3319; apar ~ id. 233-24, passim; apāc ~ to rise from the dead 10517. -- Ps. ʾhstny ʾhyc-; MPrs ʾxystn ʾxyz- (S, A--H I); < ā- + BP xistan [hstnˡ] xēz- [hyc-]; [Page39-b] MPrth ʾxʾštn ʾxyz- (S), cf KZŠPrth 1. 9 wyhšt = vīxišt, Gr. v. . Verbum 178; Ghilain 61. V. also rist-āxēz.
pres. st., imp. bē ~ *proceed ! 3924 (text perhaps defective). -- Uncertain. MPrs ʾxrʾm- ‘to pass along’, Verbum 190; NP xirāmīdan ‘to walk gracefully’. -- Coincides in writing with āhrām (q. v.).

constellation, one of the signs of the Zodiac, pl. cas. obl. ~ -ān: šagr ~ the constellation Leo 511; har ~ -ē [~ + 1] 8725; hān i 12 ~ 7717; ōišān 12 ~ 7721. 7913; 12 ~ -ān 8914; ōišān ~ -ān 7919; ōišān 12 ~ -ān 7918. 8724; 12 katak i ~ -ān 8722-23. -- MPrthPrs ʾxtr; Paz. NP axtar; v. also dvāzdah.
“Zodiac-calculator” = horoscopist, astrologer, pl. cas. obl. ~ -ān 55.9.25. -- V. s. v. ōšmurtan.

existence, life: ~ i astōmand the material, terrestrian world 378. 401 etc., passim. -- Av. (106 sqq.) ahu-, aŋhu-; FrP, Cod. P fol. 7a with the Paz. reading axui and the NP gl. dunyā. Paz. commonly ōx. -- Another axu v. patvast-axuēh.
world 3115. 4522 etc. -- Paz. axąn (Mx), āxąn (ŠGV).
belonging to the world, of the world: har 2 ~ rāyēnišn (q. v.) 6613.
discontent, displeasure: ~ kartan to cause offence 837. -- Paz. axuarsandī; v. xuansand.
stable 44. 2616.18. -- < ā- + xuar-, v. xuartan; KZŠPrth. l. 24 ʾhwr-²pty, Gr. v. ; NP āxur. Cf pat-xuar. Arm. lw. axor3; Telegdi 226.
the state of not eating: pat ~ without eating, without food 10514. -- V. xuartan.

unwillingness, both in the sense of diffidence and of [Page40-a] reluctancy: atān hān i kart (v. 2kartan) ~ dahēt he will create unwillingness with regard to what you have instituted 451, with the following gl. explaining ~: kū šmāh xuēš rād nē tuvān xuāstan, kas šmāh rād nē xuāhēt ‘~ means that you are incapable of an act of will for your own sake and nobody will be willing (to act) for your benefit’ (you will be diffident and inefficient, and nobody will work for you) 452-3; the gist of Yam's speech is expressed in the gl. 452, v. acārēnītan.
, v. patvast-axuēh.
not doing one's duty, disloyal 1625. -- V. xuēškār.
n. pr. 479. -- BdA p. 2287 Yaŋhd6 (Paz.).
gain, benefaction 94, from

ayāp-, to reach, to attain 4618.22. 805.25. 888. 1053.12. -- Ps. pt. ʾyʾpty; MPrs pt. ʾyʾpt, pres. ʾyʾb- (Verbum 176); Paz. ayāftan ayāw- (Mx, ŠGV); NP yāftan yāb-. Av. (70 sq.) ap-; āp- < ā- + ap-; ay- probably < abi-, cf Av. (71) avi-ap-. -- The pres. st. ayāp in compounds: hamāk- ~, dūr- ~, v. these ws.
to torment 612.19. -- MPrs pt. (not pres. !) ʾyʾrdyd; ʾyʾrdyšn (A--H I, II); Verbum 188.
the state of not making sacrifice 599. -- V. yazišn. Coincides in writing with izišnēh (q. v.).

to reach, to get at, to touch: ō mar gav ayinaft as for the scoundrel, (his) hands touched 6117, with the gl. kū-š ēvak pat dit frāc zat he clapped his hands together; ōi mar hān i dašn gav ō rān apar ayinaft as for the scoundrel, (his) right hand got at his hip = the scoundrel put his right hand on his hip 6120; [yōrtāi bē ahi/ayi/-naftak 4 angust būt the corn had reached the height of 4 fingers PR 299 (written ʾhdynptkˡ, a hybrid form of ahinaftak and ayinaftak, [Page40-b] with the common alternation of -y-: -h-]. -- < abi + Av. (1041) nam-, cf MPrth ʾbnft ʾhynd ‘they went off (to the tomb)’ M 1812 (S), Ghilain 73, cf Skr abhi-nam- ‘to approach a p.’; as to the development of abi- in SW cf s. v. ōmēt; as to -mt- > -ft- v. s. v. ahrām and hanžaftan. Another ʾbnftn ʾto flee’ < Av. (l. c.) apa-nam- (MHC), v. Ghilain, l. c. Cf franaftan, vīnaftakēh. NP īnaft ‘petition, need, demand’.

, *āyiyānak [ʾdywʾnkˡ] a bird's nest 409.16.25. -- Reading hypothetical; I identify the w. with MPrth ʾhyʾng = āhiyānag ‘nest’ (A--H III) < *āθiyān-, borrowed in SW and subjected there to the usual alternation -h-: -y-. The genuine SW form is found in NP āš-²yānah < *āθyāna-, with -θy- in contactual position > -šy-. As to the spelling -yw- for -iy- cf apiyuxt, giyāk, niyandar.
molten metal 10116-20. 10222. 10323. -- Borrowed from Av. (162) ayōxšusta-, ayaoxšusta-.

pres., to intend: ka āyōzāt [ʾywcʾtˡ] cikāmcihē Pourušāsp kū yazišn kunāt whenever P. intends to perform a sacrifice 5313-14. -- Av. (1231) yaoz- ‘to be agitated’; MPrth rzmy(y)wz ‘eager for battle’ (A--H III); Arm. lw. yoiz ‘commotion, trouble’, but also ‘research, investigation’ (den. vb. yuz-em ‘to agitate; to scrutinize’); -- ā-yaoz- ‘to agitate, to disturbe’: MPrth ʾʾywštn, ʾʾywz- (ʾy-) (A--H III), ʾʾywštg ‘tossing’ (sea), ʾywz ‘violent; disturbance’ (MHC). Borrowed in MPrs in the same sense (Verbum 183) and also in BP: razmīk āyōzišn [ʾywcšnˡ] ‘the act of fighting in battle-array’, NSt § 3; āyōz renders Av. yaozənte Y. 654. In SW, where ž changed to z, āyōz- coincided with āyōž- and adopted its inf. āyuxtan, cf DkM 698 pres. āyōz-, but 6815 āyux-²tārēh in the sense ‘strive for’. The genuine SW form of yaoz-: OP yaud-, v. yōd-; possibly represented by *āhōyēnītan (q. v.) = V. also hu-āyōzišn. [Page41-a]
team of horses: hān i 4 ~ rahy the four-horsed chariot, the qua-²driga 519.11.
āyōž- [ʾywc-] 1. to drive (in a car), to go by car 5219. 5618. 6112. -- 2. āyuxtan inf. of āyōz- (q. v.). -- 1. ā- + Av. (1228 sq.) yaog-. Cf api-yuxt.
to dare, to venture; governing a subordinate clause without conj.: kas nē ayyārīt frāc šavēt 1614; frāc ō pēš nē ayyārīt šavēt 2519. -- As to the ligature ayyā- v. I, 136. -- NP yārīdan ‘to be able’.

to long for, to yearn for: i ka-t ō vēnišn i Ahriman ... ayyast since thou hadst (such a) longing to see A. 762, impers. constr., cf Lat. tibi lubuit; -- [pres. ayyās- DkM 4837-8 = Cod. K 43 fol. 184 v. ult. sq.; the sense ‘to long for’ is confirmed by this passage and by the subst. ayyāsakēh ‘longing’ DkM 19122. 1924-5; cf also dēv-ayyās]. -- In 762, Cod. K has ʾdybstˡ, Anklesaria ʾdybʾstˡ without variants, Sanj. ʾdybʾtstˡ; in Mx ch. 724 (wanting in Cod. K) Anklesaria has ʾdybʾsytˡ, Sanj. again ʾdybʾtstˡ; Paz. in both places aiwiāsīd6. -- MPrs ʾyʾs- ‘to desire, to strive to’, Verbum 176. The Skr. v. of Mx took it to mean ‘to come’: 762 tvam ... prāviśaḥ, ch. 724 tvam ... samāyātaḥ. Possibly there was a vb. abi- + MPrth ʾʾs-, ʾs- ‘to come’ (A--H III, Ghilain 49) in BP.
memory 1111. 124; andar ~ dāštan to keep in memory 719. -- Ps. ʾbyʾt; MPrth ʾbyʾd, ʾn-ʾbyʾd ‘not remembering’; MPrs ʾyʾd (BBB, Sogd. 2126); Paz. ayād6, NP yād. Verbum 224.
“remembrance-work” = memorabilia, memoirs 184; memorandum 10823. 1136. -- Paz. ayādagār; NP yādgār; cf Ps. ʾbyʾtkʾlyhy ‘recollection’, MPrs ʾyʾdgʾryh ‘mention’ (S).
avidity, covetousness 664. 6813; as a demon 6813. 7713. 862. 987. 1033-15. -- [Page41-b] Av. (343) āzi-; MPrs ʾʾz; Paz. āž (!); NP āz.
pres., to molest, to harass, to injure, imp. 704. -- Av. (1670) ā-zar-; MPrs pt. ʾʾzʾrʾg (A--H I); Paz. pres. āzār-; NP āzā¤rdan āzār-. Hence
subst. oppression, harassing 91; ~ kartan to injure 2821.
v. n. of 1āzār -- molestation, oppression 6624. 838.
having no old age 5922. 774. 10410. -- V. zarmān.
unborn 4620. -- V. zāt.

1. noble, nobleman, nobility, designation of the large class of lower Sass. nobility (v. Christensen, Sass. 111-113): pl. cas. rect. ~ 264; pl. cas. obl. ~ -ān HajA: 6. B: 6 [ʾzʾtn]. 169. -- 2. set free from servitude, manumitted (of a slave), sg. cas. obl. ~ -ēh, v. s. v. dāštan. -- 1. Av. (343) ā-zāta- ‘highborn, noble’ (v. s. v. zātan), properly ‘agnate’ and therefore in the line of succession and entitled to a share in the inheritance and privileges of the clan; Arm. lw. azat; hence also Paz. āž(!)ād6, Skr. v. āḍhya ‘rich’ (ŠGV). -- 2. < ā- + Av. (1688) zāy- ‘to let out (water from a basin)’, cf ava-zāy- ‘to chase away’; MPrthPrs ʾʾzʾd ‘free’, in this sense also Arm. lw. azat and Paz. āž(!)ād6, Skr. v. svatantra ‘independent’ = NP āzād; borrowed in OAram in the expression ʾzʾt ŠBQ ‘to release’ (Pap. Kraeling). The earlier investigations of these two ws., which were as a rule regarded as one etymologically (by Bthl; Bailey, BSOS VI, 1930-1932, 70. 953-955; Gershevitch, JRAS 1954, 126; Benveniste, JA 242, 1954, 298-299), are now superseded by the short but masterly analysis given by Anahit Pe4rikhanian in RE4A, N. S. V, 1968, 9-16, establishing, with the aid of abundant Arm. material, two homonyms of widely different origin and use. [Page42-a]
true-bred, of cows 422.6; -- pl. cas. obl. ~ -ān (ʾcʾtkʾnˡ) used as pl. of āzāt (1) 1113, cf s. v. vāspuhrakān.

1. feudal benefice, fief 1173; xrat ~ the wealth of his Wisdom 917; generosity 7026. -- 2. sg. cas. obl. of āzāt (2), q. v. -- 1. From āzāt (1); Paz. āzādī, Skr. v. prabhutva ‘dominion, wealth’, āžādī, Skr v. ṛddhatva, saṃpatti ‘prosperity, abundance’ (ŠGV); MPrs ʾʾzʾdyy, ʾzʾdyy ‘inheritance’ (thus Pe4rikhanian, l. c. s. v. āzāt, p. 16; the passages from A--H II). -- 2. MPrth ʾʾzʾdyft ‘freedom’; NP āzādī ‘liberty, freedom from worldly cares’.
invocation 7011. -- Borrowed from Av. (1667 sq.) zav-, pres. zbā-.
unarmed, (war) conducted without arms 12113. -- V. zēn.
trial 41. -- V. ōzmūtan. [Page42-a]
avaricious, covetous 704. -- V. āz. Paz. āzūr, NP āzvar, āzūr.
a dragon 3115.21. -- Av. (266) aži-; Paz. až (Aog.). -- V. Aži-dahāk.

honour, renown 723; favouring, respect of persons 7222. -- MPrs ʾʾzrm ‘honour’ (BBB 53); Paz. NP āzarm. From Av. (512) abi-2gar- ‘to praise, to assent to with cheers’; < *abi-jarman- (HP II, 28: *ā-); as to abi-: ā- v. s. v. āstēnītan. Cf apa-žīrišnīk, in which api- (and secondarily apa-) has been substituted for abi-, v. s. v. apa-.
honoured 423 (comp. ~ -tar). 163. -- Cf anāžarmēh, -mihā.
an honoured position (in this life) 724. -- Paz. substitutes āzarmī.

, Aždahāk [ʾcdhʾkˡ] the name of a dragon; ~ razm “a Dragon battle”, a battle as furious as if the dragon A. were the enemy 219. 306. -- Borrowed from Av. (266, 704) Aži-dahā-²ka-; MPrs ʾzdhʾg (S, A--H I), ʾwzdhʾg (A--H I, a popular etymology); MPrth ʾzdhʾg, ʾjdhʾg, Sogd. 21 sq.; Paz. Aži-dahāk; NP aždahā. -- V. also Dahāk. [Page42-b] <H>B

B:4. ŠPrs: 8. Prth: 8; ~ Artax-²šahr HajA: 3. B:3. ŠPrs: 6. Prth: 6; 1091. 11116; ~ Šāhpuhr HajA: 1. B:1. ŠPrs: 4. 11. Prth: 4. 6. 8. P 1:1. P 2:9; ~ Ohurmazd P 1:3; ~ Xōsrōi 10921; pitar ~ P 1:10; -- pl. cas. obl. ~ -ān [ʾRḤYʾ-n, bgʾnˡ] as a pl. majestatis: ōišān ~ -ān Šāhpuhry P 2:8, without the king's name P 1:4; šmāh ~ -ān addressing the king [Page42-b] 1018. 1823-2712, passim; as a real pl. ‘lords’, of princes, noblemen, etc. 2019. -- OP Av. (921) baga-, baγa-; MPrth bg, pl. bgʾn; MPrs by, pl. bʾʾn, bʾn; MPrth ʾwhrmyzd-bg; MPrs ʾwhrmyzd-by; by zrwʾn (A--H II); Paz. pl. byąn (FrP). -- In 751 Paz. substitutes vehąn.
garden ŠPrs: 16. -- NP bāγ.
the town of Bagdad 11721.

divine providence 7713, cf the definition Mx ch. 246-7: āsn baxt hān bavēt i hac fratomēh baxt ēstēt, u bāgōbaxt hān i dit-ic baxšēnd ʾinnate baxt is that which has been allotted from the very beginning, and ~ is that which they [Page43-a] (the gods) allot subsequently’ -- Borrowed from Av. (922) baγōbaxta-; Paz. baγōbaxt, Skr. v. punar-dāti, -bhāgya.
motive, cause 8313. -- More common whʾnˡ = vahān, whʾnk = va-²hānak; MPrs whʾng (A--H II); Paz. vahąn (ŠGV), vahāna (Mx); Skr. v. kāraṇa, hetu; NP bahānah.

lot, share, portion 6920. 9010.11; (the part played by the priest in the service =) ministry 5318.19 (v. s. v. aržā-²nīkēnītan), a synonym of yazišn (q. v.); this sense is confirmed by Zsprm XII, 6: Pourušāsp bahr ō ōi hilāi kē-š patiš aržānīkēh ‘P. shall leave the bahr to the one who has the qualification for it’, corresponding to (Pourušāsp ...) yazišn ō yaštārān *hārēfāt (v. hārēftan), with the gl. kū ō yazāt kē apāyet yaštan 5314-15; -- happiness, prosperity: tan ~ bodily beauty 223. -- Av. (923) baxəδra-; Ps bhly; MPrth bhr ʾ*fateʾ; MPrs bhr (A--H I), hʾmbhr ‘having the same share’ (A--H II); Paz. bahar, Skr. v. vibhāga and samṛddhi; NP barx. [It would be tempting to connect (tan) bahr with Skr bhadra- ‘beautiful, happy’; phonetically there is no difficulty, cf Skr mudrā: muhr ‘seal’; Av. baδra- is attested in hu-baδra- (1828) ʾhappyʾ; thus Bailey in A. M., N. S. II: 1, 1952, 32].
lot, share (= bahr) 1152.
the state of being prosperous, prosperity 877.
the state of having a share in (hac), participation in 909.14. -- Paz baharvarī, Skr. v. samṛddhi, which suits the context less well.
height 3118 etc. passim; da-²hān ~ as high as to the mouth 10117. -- NP bālā; v. bālēn, bālist, buland.
the crown of the head 728. -- Paz. bālīn, Skr. v. erroneously utśīrṣaka ‘pillow’ after NP bālīn. < OP [Page43-b] *bardanya-, SW form of *barzanya- from Av. (950) barəzan- ‘top’.

1. the highest, sup. of buland (q. v.) 386. -- 2. subst. top 4016; zenith 9612. 9810. 9911; culmination point (of a star) 510. -- MPrs bʾryst; < OP *bar-²dista-, SW form of Av. (950) sup. barə-²zišta-.
pl. cas. obl., a mountain tribe, the Balochis 11514.

splendour, beam of light 11218; nazd ~ daybreak 53, v. nazd. -- MPrth Prs bʾm; Paz. bām (ʾdayʾ Aog.); NP bām; cf Av. (1468) vīspō.bāma- ‘allresplendent’, (954 sq.) bāmyā ‘the dawn’. V. uš-bām and the next w.
at dawn 716. 672. -- MPrs bʾmdʾd; Paz. bāmdād6 = NP.
brilliant 10615.22. -- MPrth bʾmyg (MHC), cf uš-bām.

tie, band, bond; fetters 919. 341 (818 probably mistaken for bry <n> = brīn, cf Mx ch. 2710; Paz. is wanting); ~ i zēndān imprisonment, captivity 93; ~ the snare of Death 6514-18; cē rād ka mēnōyān u gētīkān dānišn u kār-ākāhēh har 2 band ō tō [i. e. xrat] patvast why are knowledge and skill of both the heavenly and the earthly beings (so) closely tied up with (dependent on) thee [the Wisdom] ? 8811-12; the Skr. v. joins band with the preceding har 2: dvāvapi bandhau, but this is contradicted by 12017-18: cigōn martōmān i andar gētē band ō mēnōyān patvast ēstēt as men in this world are closely tied up with the heavenly beings. -- Av. (926 sq.) banda-; MPrth. bnd; bndystʾn ‘prison’ (MHC); MPrs bnd (A--H II), bn = bann (S, A--H I), bnystʾn = bannistān < band- (A--H I); Paz. NP band. V. bastan.
servant, slave ŠPrs: 16; 310. 516; pl. cas. obl. ~ -ān 713. -- [Page44-a] OP bandaka-; MPrth bndg; MPrs bng = bannag < bandak; Paz. banda, NP bandah.
hemp, or a similar intoxicating plant: āp i ~ 2517, āp ~ 2814 a poison made from it. -- Av. (925) bangha-, baŋha-; NP bang. Cf mang.
fruit 6613; as to 38 v. ēvar. -- Ps. bly; Paz. NP bar, but MPrthPrs bʾr.
pres. st. of burtan (q. v.), in compounds: v. paitām-bar.
burden 1188. -- = NP.
a time, in reckoning: ē ~ once 9713-14; pat ē ~ at one time 326; 2 ~ twice 9712; 3 ~ thrice 2119 etc. -- = NP; v. also ēvbār, hambār, hamvār.
adj. of 2bār in compounds: 2- ~ sāk double tax 1192.

enduring, patient 661; humble 1312. -- [PR 19812 sqq.: bāristānēh hān bavēt kē bār i ruvān, i ō tan apāyist, ka-š škiftēh apar frāc rasēt api-š ō kas tuvān spōxtan (q. v.), nē spōcēt, bē bāristānēh xuat apar patīrēt ʾb. is the quality of him who does not throw (upon another) the burden of his soul, which affects himself, when hardships befall him and he would be able to throw it upon another, but accepts spontaneously to be a bāristānʾ, in other words: who, even if he could, does not thrust upon others the burden of his soul when hardships befall him, but takes his burden upon himself. with encl. bē-c 3812, bē-p 5324, cf also 2bēš: 1. adv. outside HajB: 8; HajA: 7 LBRʾ = ō bē outward; ibd. 9 ʾL LBRʾ ŠṬRʾ = ō bē ārak id.; -- hac bē Xuanīrah from outside Kh. 10812; -- bē hac tō outside thee, thy domain 1035 (v. s. v. tō).11; -- together with a following prep.: bē ō emphasizing the sense of direction inherent in ō, very frequent; still more emphatic tāi bē ō right up to 9218; bē apar Zartuxšt nīšān (q. v.) drāyīt 487-8; -- bē ! away ! 1423. -- 2. prev.: a) off, out, away, forth, esp. with vbs. designating a motion or a change of place or of condition, v. each separate vb.; cf fratom ō ānōd apar raft, avdom bē raft he (the horse) was the first to come there, and the last to go away 4920; HajB: 8 (first BLʾ). In this case bē, as giving the vb. its specific sense, is not dropped when other preverbs or the negation are added; [Page46-b] it also accompanies the vb. in the inf., the v. n. and the pt.: bē tacēt, bē tacītan, bē tacišnēh (e. g. 564); bē šutan to go away, to disappear, bē šutak gone, vanished 52; etc. -- b) denoting the perfective aspect of the act, viz. that it comes to an end, or has its limit: with the pret. it gives it the sense of an act completed in the past, as in French the passe4 de4fini or in Lat. the perfectum historicum; with the pres. it denotes the completion of the act in the future (MiIr. has no special future tense); it is very often put before an imp., giving the order a peremptory force; also used in other expressions implying an act of will, cf apāyistan and framūtan; in this sense it does not stand together with an inf., or with a pt., nor with a negation, nor with other preverbs (which themselves give a perfective sense): bē bavēt he will be, but nē bavēt he will not be. The functions a) and b) are often difficult to keep apart. -- 3. prep. a) except, but: hēc zīvandak apāc bē nē mānēt bē hān i ēvak Arjāsp no one but A. alone 2926-27; 2415-16; 264; cārak bē man an kas xuāstan nē tuvān it is not possible to request a means from any other than me 342; followed by a subordinate clause: nišēm nē vindāt bē ka ... ō kōf i sar nišīnēnd did not find foothold except if they perched 2018-19; 2115-16; 6521 (v. pātixšāi); -- b) in frame prepositions: bē ... ēnyā, v. ēnyā; -- bē ... tāi: bē man tāi an kas nē mānd ēstēt no one except me has been spared 1527; bēZartuxšt tāi ... kas-ic nē nobody but Z. alone 9313-14; -- hac ... bē: nipēkihā i hac dēn bē writings outside (= not concerning) Religion 1097-8; hac kunišn i im bē out of the activity of this man 5212; -- c) late, for pat, as NP bi-: bē ravākēh bavēt 379 (gl.); 4717 (gl.); 5020 (editorial summary). -- 4. adversative conj. but: a) after a negative sentence or a negative part of the sentence: andar dēh nē, bē pat kustak-ē i dēh vitart 616; nē ōzanēt, bē apāc ō Kāyōs šut 4527, etc.; nē ēvāc ... bē not only ... [Page47-a] but (also) 455-6; -- b) but, however, continuing the narration: HajB: 8 (second BLʾ) [= bēš HajA: 7, v. below]; 19221. 2115 etc. -- MPrs by only with the encl. -c: byc ‘but’ (v. 4b) and in by-rwn (v. bērōn), in all other cases bʾ, to be read bă, shortened form in proclitic position (cf kʾ = ka, v. s. v. ka); MPrth byh ‘outside’, ʾc byh, ʾw byh ʾrg; conj. byc, byž ‘but, however’, Prth. inscr. bēš (v. below). Paz. bē, bi, be; NP only prev. bi-. Original form *bēt, cf bēt-ānak ‘an outsider, foreigner’; MPrs bydwm ‘outermost’ (S) = Paz. bētum (ŠGV). [MPrth byd ‘again, further’ (= MPrs dwdy) belongs to the numeral ‘two’, and not to this w.] -- BRʾ 1920 is a wrong ideogr. for bēh, opt. of būtan.

the Grand Vizier, of Jā-²māsp at Vištāsp's court 21-24. 2713; of the corresponding official at Arjāsp's court 2511. 287. -- A Prth. Arsacid title, adopted by the Sassanid kings of the 3d c., but later replaced by vazurg framatār (v. the 2nd w.); survived in independent Armenia governed by Arsacids (until A. D. 430) and in Georgia. Sas. inscr. Prth bythš, Prs bythšy KZŠ Prth a) l. 23, b) l. 25, c) l. 27 = Prs ll. 29. 31. 33 Gr. v. a) (in the list of the late Artaxšēr's officials), b) of Shapur's own vizier, c) [Page48-a] ; patron. Prth l. 28 = Prs l. 24 bythškn, Gr. v. ; Paikuli = KZŠ. Arm. lw. bdeašx (Hu7bschmann, AG 119 sq.). Georg: Armazi bilinguis (Nyberg, Eranos 44, 1946, 228-243; 233 sqq.) bṭḥš, Gr v. also on gems found there (l. c.; v. also Ērānšahr 169), Armazi “Aram.” inscr. (Altheim & Stiel, FuF 35, 1961, 172-178) pytḥš; native Kʾartʾveli patiaxši, pitiaxši (Hu7bschmann, Tschenkeli). Syr. lw. pṭaḥšā, pṭak6šā (often faultily vocalized), afṭak6šā (Hoffmann, Auszu7ge p. 34 n. 275). Amm. Marc. XXIII, 6: 14 vitaxae (“id est magistri equitum”), Gr. Hesych. , read . In dealing with its etymology the indigenous form bythš should, as a matter of course, be given preference before any deviating forms in foreign languages. In its oldest form it is, however, found in Arm bdeašx < *bdiaxš: -d- must be secondary (an original d would have given r) and go back to a t, voiced because of its proximity to the preceding b, which consequently must be the original initial consonant, not p (pt- would have remained); this phonetic state is cogently conclusive in favour of an original form *bitī¤yaxši-. The first element is *bitīya- ‘the second’, NW form of *dvitīya; Av. (963 sq.) bitya-, MPrth. bdyg (Nyberg, 1. c. 237 n. 2; Henning, Iranistik 62 n. 2); the second element has been explained by Pagliaro (RSO XII, 1929, 164 sqq.) as *axši- ʾ‘eye’ (in Av. derivatives, v. also apaxš); *bitīya-axši- ‘the second eye’ of the King, based on the idea, well attested by the classical authors and well analysed by P., of the King's officials as his “eyes”. Thus any etymology starting from initial pit- is peremptorily excluded; pit- for bit- must be due to a secondary development in the borrowing languages. Pagliaro, l. c. 160-168; Eilers IIJ V, 1962, 209 sq. (quotes Armazi pytḥš, but ignores bṭḥš !); Benveniste, Titres 65; Rundgren, OrSu XII (1963), 1964, 89-98 (oh !); etc. [Page48-b]

brother's son, nephew: kēsar ~ Caesar's (i. e. the Byzantine emperor's) nephew 11518. -- The last w. of l. 17 is quite obscure. The text of J.-A. has w ʾmtws w kysr ..., which Markwart (Cat. 16) emended to _ZY [Page49-b] ʾmtws _ZY kysr ... = i Amtōs i kēsar ~ kart ‘which Amtōs, the son of the brother of Kaisar’ built. However, his reading Amtōs is quite arbitrary, and he gives no reason for it; it is certainly not Greek, and no such Iranian name is imaginable. His attempt to situate the man so named in the history of the Roman emperors is pure fancy (Cat. 82). -- [Would it be too daring to read the name [ʾmtws] Amittōs and to regard it as a somewhat inaccurate rendering of Amyntas, the well known king of the highland of Asia Minor who died in the year 25 A. D. ? He was established as king by Antonius in the year 36 B. C., but went over to Octavianus in the year 31 B. C. and became a close friend of the emperor. He had political interests in Cilicia too (Strabo 671). It seems however doubtful whether he also extended his power to upper Mesopotamia.]

bav-: supplements the wanting inf., modal pres. and fut., imp. and pret. of h- ‘to be’: 1. as an independent vb: to become, to occur, to happen, to come true; to arise, to come into existence, to grow, to originate; to exist, to be, passim; hēc kē būt hēnd u hēc kē bavēnd u hēc kē hēnd 6417-18, cf būtān, hamē-būtēh, hamē-²bavētēh, bavētān; dānē kū fratāk rōc cē bavēt thou knowest what will happen to-morrow 218; apāyet būtan, v. apāyistan; būt i zīvist u būt i murt hēnd there were some who survived, and there were some who died 9527 sq.; būt dastavar kē-š guft there was a certain Dastur who said 1018-9; būt kē-š guft there was someone who said, erat qui diceret 10320; hēc kas nē būt kē ... dānist there was nobody [Page51-b] nē būt 625-26; bavēt ... Zartuxšt it must be Z. 6023; nē yātūk [YḤWWN-tˡ] bavat he cannot possibly be a sorcerer 3724, v. Grammar 53. -- 3. In the 3d p., together with a subst. virtually in dat., or with a pron. in cas. obl., it expresses the notion ‘to have’, e. g. ōi kē-š zan nē būt he who did not have a wife 1011; amāvandēh ... i-m būt the vigour which I had 344; -t dānākēh bavēt wisdom will be allotted to thee 595; duxtar i varzēkarān ēn hunar ... i tō hast nē bavēt a farmer's daughter cannot have such an ability as thou hast 1520-21; with rād as in NP: Pāpak rād hēc fradand nē būt P. had no child 16-7. -- 4. Together with verbal or other nouns it forms periphrastic verbal expressions: (i) matār būt hēnd who used to go 617; nikērāi (q. v.) bavēt 8214; tō ... āstišn nē būt hāh thou wouldst not have subsisted 3515-16; 3421-22; -š hān zan ... ayyāt būt he remembered that woman 1111-12; 123-4; -š vāt hayyār bavēt the wind helps him 253; Ohurmazd ziyān nē bavēt O. will suffer no harm 7727; v. also ākasī, hangir-²tīkēh. -- 5. With preverbs: andar ~, v. andar; -- apāc ~ to become again 7714-15. 10021-22. 12023; to come into existence again, to be restored to life 469. 1041626; to be left, to remain 3927. 4416; -- apāk ~ = apāc ~ 3423; as to 161-2. 2426-27, v. apāk; -- apar ~ to be imparted to 8018; -- frāc ~ to recover (hac from) 544912. 6022; -- ō ~ to approach, to come on 65; to pass into 4216-17; -- ō ham ~ to be put together, to be formed (from different elements) 4317; v. also hambavišnēh. -- 6. As an auxiliary vb. added to the pt. pret., būt forms the pluperf. in dependent clauses, as against ēstāt in independent sentences: pas hac hān i Artaxšēr hān kirm ōzat būt after A. had slain this dragon 818; 3511. 3615-16. 4117-18. 5110. 924. 1089; hast i mat būt 11023 (but of course always būt ēstāt); -- the pres. of ~ forms the fut. perf.: nām i yāvētak ō xuēš kart bēt 915; 1924. 10322-23. 1048. -- V. also ham-būtan. -- Common Iranian. [Page52-a] who knew 1216-8; būt i ka nē būt ... u bavēt ka nē bavēt there was a time when he did not exist, and there will be a time when he will not exist 642-3; ō(h) ~, v. ō(h); cf bavišn. -- 2. as copula, with a noun, a pron. or a prep. + subst. as its complement, passim: hān būt Vahuman 566; martōm ... hamāk ahōš ... bavēnd will be immortal 1049-10; kanīcak pat giyāk

having (all) eyes fastened (on oneself) = exposed to people's (contemptuous) looks, an object of derision, dishonoured, pl. cas. obl. ~ -kāyān [-kʾdʾnˡ], comp. [cšmkʾstl] cašm-²kāh-tar (thus K; TD_2 [cšmkʾdtl] cašm-²kāi-tar) 7522-23. -- MPrs cšmgʾh in the same sense (SalM III-IV, no. 9b5; Henning, GGN 1932, 223 n. 4, where, however, the pejorative sense is not recognized). The alternation -kāh: -kāi is also found in the parallel formation tars-kāh (PT 659 -kʾs): tars-kāi (DkM 48117) ‘reverential, respectful’, abstr. tars-kāhēh (-kʾsyh) ibd. 1. 21, but Cod. K (ad l.) tars-kāyēh (-kʾdyh). Same formation in MPrs gylgʾy (S; Verbum 205) < *gil-kāi ‘lamenting’; shykʾ = sahīk-kā(i) ‘frightened’ (preserved -k- indicates -kk-), v. also mānā(k)-kāi. [Page54-a] -- -kāi < *kāya- ‘regard, look’, cf Skr cāyati, -te ‘to notice, to observe, to behold’, kāya- ‘goal, aim’ (not to be confounded with kāya- ‘body’); root kā-, v. ākāh, nikāh, and gukāi, in which the same alternations in the final are observed. -- Neriosengh mistook the last element of ~, which he found in the form -kāh, for kāh- ‘to diminish’, Paz. xāh-, hence his reading cašm-xāhišn(itar); Skr. v. adarśanīya(tara).
