villager, pl. cas. obl. ~ -ān 146. -- A recent formation of deh; NP dihqān, Arab. lw. dihqān- ‘landlord’.
pot, vessel 428. -- NP dēg.

religion, esp. the Mazdayasnian faith, doctrine and religious order: 27. 196. 365. etc. passim.; the full expressions are: ~ māzdesn 362.3. 10913.26. 1114. 11211; māzdesn ~ 10810; ~ i māzdesnān 211723. 2322. 10126; vēh ~ or in one w. vēh-dēn [ŠPYL-dynˡ or wdhdynˡ, v. vēh] 366. 515. 11127. 11231719; ~ (i) vēh i māzdesnān 8023. 8924-25; ēn ~ i vēh i māzdesnān 9021; vēh ~ (or vēh- ~) i māzdesnān 596. 6313. 6421-23; ~ i pōr-²yōtkēšēh 6414; vēh ~ i pōryōtkēšān 1114-5; ~ i rāst i vēh 911; ēn ~ (i) apēcak 19319; ēn ~ (i) apēcak i māzdesnān 186923; [Page62-a] ēn apēcak ~ i māzdesn 2424; vēh ~ i apēcak 5914; (ēn) apēcak vēh ~ i māz-²desnān 819. 844; ~ i Ohurmazd 6026; ~ stāyītan, ~ yaštan: v. these ws; -- in particular: the authoritative canonical texts of this religion: ēn ~, cigōn hamāk apastāk u zand namely, the whole Avesta and commentary 1078; the quotations from these texts are introduced by the following formula: cigōn ~ gōbēt followed by kū 3613-14. 42113. 4520. 4615. 48418. 49116. 5224. 536. 541-17; followed by hat (q. v.) 387-8. 4325-26. 4414-15. 503-5; without following particle 4116; (i) cigōn ēt i ~ gōbēt kū 5323-24. 563. 584. 608. 617-8; cigōn pat ~ 7718; pat hān i ~ gōbēt kū 434-5; andar ~ guft ēstēt 8011; an-ic ~ gōbēt kū 3819; hac ~ (ētōn) paitāk kū 341. 8612-13; cigōn hac apēcak vēh- ~ i māzdesnān paitāk 818-9; v. further paitāk and paitākēh; v. also s. v. dipīvarēh. -- Av. (662 sqq.) daēnā-; Arm. lw. den; MPrthPrs dyn religion, religious community, church; Paz. dīn. -- Cf ak-dēnēh, dēn-burtār, dēnīk, dušdēn, hudēn.
a bearer, an adherent of the Mazdayasnian religion 1009; designates the layman as opposed to the clergy, pl. cas. obl. ~ -ān 10713-14; 972 (for cas. rect.).
n. pr. P 1:7. -- Reading not quite certain. It may be the abbreviation of one of the numerous compound names beginning with Dēn (Dēn-Ohur-²mazd, Dēn-Šāhpuhr, Dēn-ayyār, Dēn-dāt etc., v. Justi, NB).
belonging to the (Mazdayasnian) religion 969. 1054.

“Religion's Decisions”, the title of the well-known collection of traditions, the Dēn-kart: 1112-3. 11221; [Page62-b] headings 36, 108, 110, 111. -- As to the etymology of -kart, v. 2kartak and kartakān.

anger; pat ~ dāštan (to hold in anger =) to keep in custody, to arrest 2120.24. -- MPrth dybhr or tybhr ‘anger’; dybhrg tybhrg, ‘banished’ (MHC); Arm. lw. dipah ‘arrest; guard-room’, i dipahoj× dnel or arkanel ‘to place in arrest, to throw into prison’. V. Henning in MHC s. v. dybhrg.

*full of wrath 10316. -- Cf Ps. dypsty, dypšny rendering Syr rug1zā ‘wrath’. Text spspynʾ, corrected by Dhabhar to spstynˡ and combined with NP sapist ‘nasty’. This spstynˡ may, however, be read dypstynˡ as well; the assumed meaning of this w. would suit the context better. [MPrs ʾnpspyn M 985 (S) is indistinctly written and quite uncertain].
long 913. -- Paz. dērang. Cf Bthl, MirM VI, 12 n. 2.
the longdominating god, of Vāi 9913.14. 1065. -- Renders Av. (696) darəγō.xuaδāta-; also the epithet of Zurvān.
shape, form, v. xāyak-dēs. -- MPrs dys; NP -dēs, e. g. māh-dēs ‘moonlike’; v. also uzdēs. From daēs-, v. dištan.

*directions, instructions 5515. -- From Av. (672 sq.) daēs- ‘to show, to indicate, to instruct’, cf MPrth ʾbdys ‘indication, instruction’, pt. ʾbdyšt, pres. ʾbdys- ‘to show, to inform’. Ghilain 61; v. also avdišt.

demon, devil, of individual evil beings: Āz, Damistān, Frāizišt, Hešm, Zēšt, v. these ws.; -- commonly in pl.: ~ cas. rect. 1924. 451. 6917. used as voc. 4215; cas. obl. ~ -ān [ŠYDʾ-ʾnˡ, usually ŠYDʾ-nˡ] passim, used as cas. rect. 612. 7622; ~ -ān ~ the supreme devil 4215; ~ -ān dāt, v. dāt. -- Av. (667 sqq.) daēva-, OP daiva-; common MiIr and NP. [Page63-a]

one who longs for, attaches himself to the devils, pl. cas. obl. ~ -ān 639-10. -- V. ayyastan. A popular transformation of, or a euphemism for, Av. (671) daēva-yaz-, nom. sg. and pl. daēva-yāzō, cf dēv-īzak.
devil-worship 6315. -- Abstr of dēvēsn < Av. (670 sq.) daēva-yasna-.
worshipping the devils, sup. ~ -tom 535. -- A recent compound of dēv + īzak < *yaza-ka-, cf īzišn; the Phl. rendering of Av. daēva-²yaz-, v. dēv-ayyās.
devil-worship 7112. 736. 7510. 8221. -- Paz. dēvāžaī, var. dēviāžī, dēvāzī.
with demonical desire 4614.
bravery 41.
2319 (2416.20), dil-nēv [dl TB] 2920. (301.4): “good of heart” = brave, gallant. -- dilē cas. obl. of dil, v. nēv.

secretary ŠPrs: 9. 15. P 1: 7; pl. cas. obl. ~ -ān mahist the chief secretary 1118. 1821. 1925. -- FrP 15, MS K dpywl (= dipīvar). OIr *dipī-vara- from OP dipī- ‘inscription’, BP dyp ‘document’, MPrth dyb ‘letter’ + *vara- from Av. (1360) ˡvar- ‘to cover, to hide, to preserve’, thus ‘he who preserves the documents’. Early contracted to dipīr: Arm lw. dpir ; KZŠPrth l. 24 dpyrwpt = Prs 1. 29 dpyrpt, Gr. transliteration , ‘chief secretary’; M PrthPrs dbyr; NP dibīr, dabīr (but Paz. *divēr, v. next w.). Cf Bailey, BSOS VII, 1933, 76-77.
11311. dipīrēh [dpy²ryh] 226: the art of writing (documents) [Page63-b] 226; dēn ~ the writing down of the sacred texts 11311. -- MPrs dbyryy, M Prth dbyryft; Paz. divērī (Mx). Bailey, ZP 177-194.

*treated, manipulated, or the like: pat Hēšm zahr ~ *treated with (the demon) Wrathʾs poison 2516-17 = 2814. -- In the edition the first letter is a marked d, hence the reading dystkˡ is cogent. Because of -ist- this must be a SW form corresponding to a NW form with -išt-, but its meaning in this context make it impossible to combine it with NW dištan (v. next w.): a weapon is not “built” or “formed”. It would be tempting to connect it with Skr dih- ‘to daub, to smear’, but the corresponding Av. (673) daēz- has other significations (cf diz), and the Phl. renderings of it (Vd 39.13.18. 753. 1536) have run wild and are no more recognizable (they can scarcely be brought together with dēs-, v. the next w.).

to build, is the probable reading of the Prth ideogr. BNY-HajA: 9. 11: pt. = pret. pass. 3d p. sg. BNY-t = dišt, cond. BNY-t ḤWH-ndy = dišt ahēndē. -- MPrth dyštn, pres. certainly dys-, cf dysmʾn ‘building’; MPrs dysydn dys- (A-- H I), which is probably a denom. of dēs (q. v.), borrowed from NW; BP has dēsītan, pass. dēsihistan, dēsak ‘form’ (Bailey, ZP 94 n. 2), whereas the form dhytkˡ ‘built’ DD 363 seems to represent the true SW form *dahītak < *dēhītak (with -ēh - > -ah- cf s. v. uzdahīkēh) from SW *daiθ-). Sogd δys- BBB p. 56 ult.

1. the second, the other: rōc i ~ 83; ōi i ~ the other 12116; ēvak apāk ~ 10424 etc.; ēvak ō (ōi) ~ 1009.13 etc. -- 2. adv., also ~ -ic, for the second time, again 462-3 etc.; further, then 515; back P 2:10; -- 1116 v. dīt. -- Shortened from **ditī < *ditīya-, SW form of OIr *dvitīya- ‘second’, OP duvitīya-, Gath. Av. (963 sq.) daibitya- for *dbitīya-; MPrs dwdy = dudī for *didī through in- [Page64-a] fluence of dō; Paz. did6, didi-ca, dud6; as against NW *bitīya-, Av. (l. c.) bitya-; MPrth byd; cf. s. v. bītaxš. V. also ditīkar.

form.trl: [ḤZYTN-tˡ; 1116 with wrong ideogr. TWB6 for dytˡ misread as dit]

entry.sense: sight: pat ~ visibly 1116; pat ~ āvurtan to make manifest, to give evidence of 42. -- NP padīd; p. āvurdan = BP.

vēn-, 2nd p. sg. ḤZ6YTN-yd6 = vēnē 764. ḤZ6YTN-ʾh = vēnāh 313; subju. 1st p. sg. ḤZYTN-n = vēnān P 2: 10: to see, to regard, to catch sight of, to contemplate, to discern, to experience: ayāftan u ~ u dānistan 888; dānākihā ~ 5119; pat vēnišn ~ 5013-14; pat (xuēš) cašm ~ 7420. 809; -- with kū that 115. 127 etc., with ka that 4024; -- with a pt. as its complement: -m murtak dīt hān tahm spāhpat I saw this valiant general slain 2710-11; 2 zan nišastak dīt 617; with an adj. P 2:10. 2710. 5726 sq. (purr complement); -- with an indir. interrog. clause: ~ kū ... cigōn to see how 2518-19; ka-t dīt kū kas kē ... kart 737-8 a contamination between ka-t dīt kū kas ... kart and ka-t dīt kē ... kart; -- apar ~ to find out, to discover 394-5; to survey 5817; to outwit (pat) 9917; -- frāc ~ to forebode 4722. 5024. 5112-16.18-19. -- Av. OP (724 sq.) 2dāy- and (1323 sq.) vaēna-, vaina-; common. V. also vēnišn.
appearance, looks 1410. 1516.21. -- MPrth dydn ‘sight, phenomenon, aspect’, also spelt dydyn, dydʾyn (MHC).

1. ordinal number: the second: fratom ... ~ ... sitīkar etc. 8316-18; regularly placed before its subst., but at times also after: rōc i ~ 1197; sāl <i> ~ 974-5; to be noticed: ~ yašt or yašt-ē 10015. 1031.26-27. -- 2. pron.: ēvak ... ~ the one -- the other 1815-16; apāk ~ with each other 41. -- 3. adv. secondly 825; for the second time, again 439. -- SW form of OIr. *dvitīya-kara-, v. dit; Paz. dadī-²gar, NP dīgar through haplology. MPrs [Page64-b] has dwdyg, MPrth b(y)dyg (beside byd); cf dit.
the government office 11124. 1122.7.13. -- NP dīvān, Arab. lw. dīwān; Arm. lw. diwan already in the Bible. Possibly < *dipi-vahana- ‘document house’, v. dipīvar.
a wall 3923. -- NP dīvār. V. Hu7bschmann, PSt 65, no. 599, whose etymology is quite satisfactory: *dida-²vāra-, v. the next w.
castle 2326.27. 241.3.6. 10817. 11111-13. -- MPrthPrs dyz (S, A--H II, MHC); NP diz. -- NW form, as against OP didā-. From Av. (673 sq.) daēz-; cf s. v. distak.
two. -- SW form < *dāu, OIr *dvāu; MPrthPrs dw. -- Cf s. v. vicītan.

*he who has two water jugs = *the constellation Aquarius 510. -- My guess. On the Dendera picture of the Zodiac the Aquarius carries two jugs from which water flows. The reading dwʾcdhʾnˡ = dvāzdahān (q. v.) adopted by Antiā0 (following Noeldeke) does not suit the context, and the emendation *Nahāzīgān ‘Capricornus’ proposed by Sanjana is of no value.
spiritual eye, intuition 5226. -- Borrowed from Av. (744) dōiθra- ‘eye’.

detailed, full, exhaustive exposition: ~ -ē ōšmurtan drāž it would be too long to give a detailed account 10523-24; ... kē ~ dērang id. BdA p. 20914, as in Arab allad6ī ṭāla d6ikruhu; pat ~ in full detail, exhaustively 1135. -- Paz. ŠGV V, 26. 29 dugą, Skr. v. vistīrnam, XVI, 10 Skr. v. vyakti; XI, 129 dugānihā, Skr. v. prācuryena. In BdA, l. c., the first letter is a marked d. The reading seems thus to be sure and not liable to emendation (against Bailey, BSOS VII, 1935, 761-762). Probably identical with the [Page65-a] next w., properly ‘going through over again, repetition’.
double; cloven (hoof) 9418; a pair 725. -- MPrs dwgʾng ‘twofold’ (A--H II); NP dugānah ‘double’. Cf ēvkānak.
double, twice, in ~ vasihā twice as much 10924.
a biped, pl. cas. rect. ~ 197; cas. obl. ~ -ān 6912. -- V. pād and cf cahār-pād and dō-zang.
a pail, a bucket 533. -- Arab. lw. dauraq ‘a water-pot with handles’; NP daurah ‘a wine-measure’.

the name of one of the two armies commanded by the kings of Ḥīra 1177. -- In Arabic sources dausar, properly ‘having two heads’, perhaps because this army consisted of both infantry and cavalry. Nyberg, Karlgren vol., v. s. v. bōr-gil.
the act of milking; as pred. (is) to be milked 543.7.11.

to milk 426. 10122. -- Root *dheugh-, OIr *daug-, Skr duh-, cf NP dūγ ‘churned sour milk’. dōs- probably < *dōx-s- with the Prth. pres. suff. -s-, Ghilain 79 sq. -- NP dōšīdan with an unexplained -š-.
milker 543.7.11.

1. adj. kind, friendly 8320. 10413; dear, beloved, comp. ~ -tar 2218. 419. -- 2. subst. friend 3215. 6210. 6325; pl. cas. obl. ~ -ān 701222. -- < *dauštā, nom. sg. of OP dauštar-; MPrs dwst (S); Paz. NP dōst; SW forms from Av. (1656) zaoš- ‘to enjoy’; cf dōšāram.
friendship 51. 5527. 7023.
shoulder 331. -- Av. (674) daoš-; NP dōš.

foolish, stupid, ugly, comp. ~ -tar 756. Paz. reads duštar, probably only due to association with the preced- [Page65-b] ing duš-kanīk (an independent w. *duš does not exist), but perhaps meant as dušt-tar, NP dušt ‘foul, ugly’, -- Paz. dōšī ‘folly’ (ŠGV X, 58 etc.).
love, affection 51. 826 etc. -- MPrs dwšʾrm, -myh, -myy love, dwšʾrmgr ‘loving’; Paz. dušār(a)m. < dōš + āram: dōš SW form of Av. (1656) zaoša-, MPrth zwš ‘willingness’ (MHC); āram cf s. v. rāmišn.
hell 2015. 347.27. 6512.18 etc. passim; andar ~ 2516. 2813. 316. 612. 6811; pat ~ 768-11. 8419-20. -- Av. (675) daožahva-; MPrth dwjx; MPrs dwšwx; Arm. lw. džox-kʾ; Paz. dōžax, NP dōzax.
a biped, of demoniac beings, pl. cas. obl. ~ -ān 4611. -- V. zang and cahār-zang; renders Av. (966) bi-²zangra-.
banner 2722. 298.16. -- Av. (771 sq.) drafša-; MPrth drfš (A--H III, cf MHC 119 n. 1 and Gloss. s. v.); Arm. lw. drauš; NP dirafš.

to shout (with a voice resembling the neighing of a horse) 5819. -- Skr hrād- ‘to sound, to ring’, whence Av. *zrād- and OP *drād-, which developed in SW to drāy- or drāh-; hence drāi (q. v.). Thus drāhītan is ultimately identical with drāyītan (q. v.).
a silver coin, the drachm 68. 1196. -- From Gr . In Sassanian time its weight was 4. 25 gr. silver.
, dranāi [dlnʾy] length 6514. 9616, etc. -- From drāž; the form is influenced by pahnāi (q. v.). Paz. dranāē (ŠGV).
bell 2027. -- < *drāda-, SW form, v. drāhītan; NP darāi.
space of time 542.6.11. -- NP dirang ‘delay, hesitation’.

*persevering, persistent: xuāstan ~ būt hēnd they continually, [Page66-a] perseveringly sought 4511-12. -- I connect it with Av. (772) 1drang- ‘to fasten, to strengthen’; cf MPrth pres. drxs- ‘to hold out, to hold on, to persevere’ ŋ(A²H III); Ghilain 51. 93.
recitation (by heart), recital 7315. 7516.18. -- From Av. (772 sq.) 2drang-; Paz. drenžešn, Skr. v. vākya (Mx), pralāpa (ŠGV).
det. v. n. = the preceding w.: xūp ~ eloquence, rhetorical power 7022.
tree 4015.16; pl. cas. rect. ~ 3316, cas. obl. ~ -ān 1420. -- MPrthPrs drxt; Arm. lw. draxt ‘garden’; Paz. d(a)-²raxt; NP diraxt.

the sea 621. 2113. 11313. -- SW form of Av. (1701 sq.) zrayah (v. zrāh, zrāi): OP drayah- + āp; the compound was quite clear to those who created the Aram. expression used later as ideogr. (FrP 3): YMYMYʾ, i. e. yammē mayyā ‘seas of water’, a purely mechanical transposition of dray(ah)-āp ‘seawaters’. MPrs dryʾb (A--H I); Paz. daryāv; Ps. has the bizarre spelling dlywʾw (cf s. v. niyandar); NP daryā.

the act of chewing performed by one who is chattering: ~ kartan to chew when chattering (we would prefer to say: to chatter when chewing) 6910. -- drāyān pt. of the next w.; jōyišnēh det. v. n. of jūtan (q. v.). Paz. drāeą jōišnī. Skr. v. mauna-²madhye jalpa ‘chatter in the midst of silence’, i. e. where silence ought to prevail.

to howl, to talk, of demoniac beings 4817.27 etc.; with an obj. 487-8, v. nīšān; -- also: to chatter, to prate’, v. the preceding w. -- From OP *drād-, v. s. v. drāhītan. In the SW development intervocalic -d- became -y- as usual: drāyītan, but this -y- could be dropped and -h- inserted in the hiatus: drāhītan; the two forms have then been differentiated as to use and meaning. [Page66-b] Paz. drāīdan drāēd6; NP darāyīdan ‘to speak aloud’.

long, comp. ~ -tar; ~ pat bālāi elevated, high 389; with an inf.: it would be too long to ... 10524, v. dōkān. -- Av. (773 sq.) drājah- ‘length’; adj. comp. drājyō, sup. drājištəm; Paz. drāž (ŠGV); NP dirāz.

1. adj. poor, lacking in (hac), comp. ~ -tar 9018. -- 2. subst. a religious term designating a class of pious men and women, pl. cas. obl. ~ -ān 5312. -- Borrowed from Av. (777 sq.) drigu-, driγu- (in nom.); Paz. daryōš, Skr. v. durbala; NP darvēš, old darγōš, daryōš. Cf Bailey, BSOS VI, 1930, 70; Barr, Pedersen Vol. (1953), 21-40.

drīn- [SDKWN-] to tear to pieces, to slit 502. 1027-8 (v. s. v. dāštan). -- Av. (689) 1dar-, pres. dərənā- (Skr middle dṛṇīte). Reading according to FrP 18; BP also darrītan darr- = NP dar(r)īdan dar(r)-.

, drōb [dlwbˡ] lie, falsehood 326. 836. 8427. 8620. F: 7; gukāhēh i pat ~ false witness 7314. 7518; -- adj. unjust: ~ dātavarēh 7313; dātavarēh i ~ 7517; -- adv. unjustly 799. -- Av. (768) draoga-²draoγa-, OP drauga-; NW forms: MPrth drwg; Paz. d(a)rōg, NP durōγ; SW forms (with -γ > -v) drōv, Ps. dlwby, MPrs drw (A--H II). -- On kdbʾ 2217 v. kai-bāg.

benediction (in salutations, etc.), welfare, prosperity 1419. 1710. 1918. 12120; ~ ō ruvān dātan to say farewell to one's life, to die 293-4. -- < OIr *druvatās, nom. of Av. (782 sq.) drvatāt-; MPrthPrs drwd; Paz. drūd6; NP durūd.
v. druxtan.
a liar 2223; pl. cas. obl. ~ -ān 12810. -- Av. (769) draojina-; OP draujana-; MPrs drwzn; from druxtan. [Page67-a]
untruth 794. -- MPrs drwznyy (S, A--H I); Paz. družanī.
stronghold, citadel 11715. -- Paz. drūpuštī; dru- ‘firm’: v. druyist.
rough, harsh, coarse, v. next w. -- NP durušt.
in a manner characteristic of a društ-ēvāc, a man whose speech is coarse, a coarse-spoken man 412. -- V. ēvāc.
to cut off, to mow: apar drūt 417. -- FrP 18 drūtan drūn-; Paz. pres. drūn- (Mx); NP durūdan dirav-, but durūn ‘a measure of corn’.

wicked, evil, of Ahriman 642.7 and passim; of human beings 109. 3414. 6625. 964. 10711 -- subst. 7213. 7417, pl. cas. obl. ~ -ān 4611. 5313. 7220. 7421. 755. 10226. 10322, used as cas. rect. 1011418. -- Av. (774 sqq.) drəgvant-, drvant- ‘belonging to the drug’ (v. druž); MPrs drwnd (S, A--H II); Paz. daruand, dar-²vand.
wickedness 689; the state of being wicked 7424; coll. the wicked 8215 (Paz. substitutes darōg). -- Paz. daruandī.
2119 must designate the lower end of the arrow, but its etymology is quite obscure: *druva- ‘firm’ (v. druyist) + ? -- It cannot be the Avestan (783) deity Drvāspā.

safe and sound, whole; right, exact, accurate: P 2:9. 10 (twice). 1418. 2222 etc. passim. -- The letters are unmistakable in P 2. Av. (782) drva-²(= druva-); OP duruva- ‘firm, secure’, sup. *druvišta-, whence in SW druyist [Page67-b] with -uvi- > -uyi- and -št- > -st-. MPrth drwšt; MPrs dryst; Paz. d(u)rust, društ; NP durust.
v. tan-druyistēh.

all that is false, untrue, wrong, deceptive: 1. the world of Guile and Untruth, conceived as a personal cosmic power, 3822. 9313. -- 2. individual manifestations of this power, demons, conceived as feminine supernatural beings: sg. 5716-25. 583. 9620-24. 9817-19. 10125 (voc.). 1023-14; ~ i anāštēh 671; ~ i spazgēh 6811-12; ~ i ahramōg 10124-25; pl. cas. rect. ~ 648. 654. 9721. 9819 (of human beings). 10224-27. 1033; pl. cas. obl. ~-ān in the set phrase dēvān u ~ -ān 7511 etc. (voc. 9027). V. also mihr-druž, mihrān-druž. -- Av. (778 sqq.) drug-, nom. druxš, gen. drūjō; MPrs drwxš (S); Paz. drūž.
falsity, unrighteousness 666; a troop, band of fiendish beings 9625. V. also mihrān-družēh.
n. pr., Zartuxštʾs mother 4112. 425.8.24. 432. 4721. -- Av. (748) Duγdō.vā-.
tail: brīt- ~ 2418, v. brī-²tan; burrītak- ~ -ē (-ē in attributive position) 302-3, v. burrītak. -- Av. (749) duma-; NP dumb, dunb. Cf. gaz-dum, gāž-dumb.
Mount Damavand 11513. -- KZŠPrth 1. 24 dwnbʾwntš, Gr. v. , ibd. 1. 26 id., = Prs 1. 32 dwnbʾwncy, Gr. v. - ; Eilers, AOi4 22, 1954, 267-374; 24, 1956, 183-224.
far, distant, aloof 152. 2727 etc. passim. -- Av. OP (750) dūra-; common.

entry.sense: dem. pron. this, subst. (mostly n.) and adj., no pl.; very common in the Dk text 37-61, scarce in other texts, except ~ [Page69-b] rād (v. below). 1. ḤNʾ: ~ nāmaky this inscription (here above) P 2:3; ~ vizand hac yātūkēh i ~ kanīk 3713: ~ -ic ēvak hac avdēh the following is one of the miracles 4424; kē hac ~ aštak, vēh he [Page70-a] who is the messenger from this being [the Creator just mentioned] is good 5711; etc. passim; -- anticipates a clause with kū ‘that’ 521712. 5320; ~ kū the fact is that 527; a rel. clause: ~ i-t ... pursīt 7614; ~ cē that which 11214; -- forms a rel. attribute: ~ i vas kayak u karap 5525; -- forms possessives of the pers. pronouns: ~ i man zan my wife 3215; ~ i tō pus thy son 5213-15; ~ i tō separated by other parts of the sentence from its headw. 605; -- pat ~ dāštan 5012, v. dāštan; pat ~ šātēhē for joy over this 4120; pat ~ kū ... adak-ic although ... yet 5525-26; ~ rād for that reason 795 etc.; -- cigōn ~ i dēn gōbēt as the pertinent passage of the Scripture says 5323 etc.; ēvak ~ i paitāk kū one (event) is that which is revealed, namely that 38517. -- 2. ḤWHw-ytˡ (ideogr. for the 2nd p. pl. of h- ‘to be’) wrongly for ēt: pat ~ dāštan 2525. -- 3. ē: ēvak ~ (i) paitāk 3610 and passim 41-54; ~ rād cē because 9422. -- Av. (12 sqq.) aēta-, OP aita-; MPrth ʾyd; MPrs ʾyd. The form ēt in BP is confirmed by the wrong ideogr. ḤWHw-ytˡ, but it is noteworthy that this pron., wherever it is phonetically written in BP, has the form ē (also in FrP 25). In Paz. there is no trace of ēt (ēd), since the only form occurring there is ē with the pl. ēšąn, which is also used as the pl. of ōi, ōišān having totally disappeared; NP has only ō, pl. ēšān. This ēšąn can neither be derived from ēt nor from ōišān; it must reflect the OIr. gen. pl. *aišām (Av. aēšąm) of *ayam (Av. ayem, aēm) whence in MiIr *ēš enlarged with the MiIr pl. ending -ān. The most probable explanation of BP ē is, therefore, that it is not a mutilation of ēt but the gen. sg. of *ayam: ahya. This being so, it would seem to be most advisable simply to give ē as the normal equivalent of ḤNʾ, which would best explain the widely spread use of HNʾ as the ideogr. for homonyms, v. below. -- to please to, to deign to, with inf. 1122-26. 1419; -- kār framūtan = kār kartan 27, v. kār; -- the order itself is expressed 1. in dir. speech by an imp. introduced by kū: framūt kū “nikēr” 45; 1213. 3322; a surplus, or a remainder, a rest: martōm (indir. obj.) ~ pat nēvakō-²kēh <i> hān kunēnd i-šān andar gēhān apāyišnīktar vēh dīt to mankind they (the gods) will make a surplus above the felicity which in this world was seen by them as the most exquisite and the very best 10025-26 i. e., mankind will be given a felicity above the most exquisite and the very best felicity they experienced in this world. -- Paz. frēž-, frēz- (v. next group) = BP frēc < *frarēc (haplology) < OIr *fra-raica- (from fra + raik-, v. rēxtan), cf Skr prarecana- ‘surplus’, pra-²reka- ‘abundance’, properly ‘what is projecting’. To it belongs the vb. frēxtan frēc- 1. ‘to be over, to be left, after necessary expenses, as a gain or a rest’, 2. ‘to put aside what is surplus, to save’, or, ‘to increase by a surplus’. Cf (Paz.) nē nēkī frēžašnī ... rā ‘not in order to add to the well-being’ ŠGV III, 24, Skr. v. śubhasya visphītaye; har cē frēcēt hac all that is left of, or after BdA p. 1107 (plycytˡ with the first y marked) = BdJ 397; PY 6822; frēxt ‘savings’ PVd. 329. 1838 (comm.). Bthl., followed by others, read parēc- < *pari-raica-, identifying it with Sogd pʾrʾyc- ‘to leave, to abandon’ (Zair Wb 52; MIrM I, 14. II, 11. 38 sq.) and adducing as a parallel Gr . However, the Paz. reading frēž is firm, unimpeachable and transparent, and as representing a living WIr tradition it is preferable to any reading based on EIr material (besides, Sogd pʾrʾyc- seems to [Page79-a] be a secondary form of ʾprʾyc-, prʾyc-, Gauthiot 126, Benveniste, GS 19). Cf also Dhabhar, PYV, Gl. p. 80. -- This vb. coincides graphically with pardaxtan par-²dac- [pldhtnˡ pldc-] q. v.; this has caused some confusion: 7616 Paz. has frēž whereas only pardac (marked d in Cod. K) is appropriate; ŠGV III, 24 West, followed by de Menasce, conjectured pardacišnēh, rejecting frēž- which is, however, the adequate vb. there.

KnS VI, 8 = KnA p. 275. -- OP *garda- attested by the Bab. lw. gardu in deeds and documents of the Achaemenian epoch (a gardu-patu = OP *garda-pati- is also mentioned), and by the Aram. lw. grdʾ in the Fayyum pap., v. Driver, Doc., [Page80-b] ad letter VII1. In Elamitic transliteration kurtaš, v. Cameron, Persepolis Treasury Tablets (1948), passim. These villeins were slaves recruited from war prisoners and non-Aryan peoples, v. M. Danda-²mayev, Foreign slaves on the estates of the Achaemenian kings and their nobles (XXV International Congress of Orientalists, Papers presented by the USSR delegation, Moscow 1960). Previous researches: Eilers, ZDMG 90, 1936, 193-196; AfO 17, 333a; AOi4 22, 1954, 353 sq.; Henning apud Gershevitch, A. M., NS II, 1951, 141-142; Benveniste, JA 242, 1954, 306. -- Another subst. formed through Ablauf from the same st.: *gṛdha-, Skr gṛha- ‘servant, house’, Av. (522 sq.) gərəδa- ‘cave, dwelling-place of demons’, Arm. lw. gerda-stan ‘body of servants (Ev. Luc. 12: 42); property’, has survived in the sense of ‘herd’ in WIr gal(l)ah, gil etc., v. s. v. bo7r-gil.

, ganāi [gnʾy], ganā [gnˡ-ʾ] 1. murderer, of a human being 5414. -- 2. ~ mēnōi the Evil Spirit, designation of Ahriman 466-7. 642.7. 656. 6626. 67714. 7526. 765. 1021-2.16.17. 1034.21-. 10512; without mēnōi: gizistak ~ i druvand 8012. 9025. -- From gan- ‘to slay’, v. zatan; cf BdA p. 4811-12: ganākēh<i> hast zatārēh. -- ~ mēnōi is the MiIr. translation of Angra-²mainyu-, Aŋra-m., v. Ahriman, and ~ corresponds to angra-, aŋra-, which is rendered in the Skr. vs. by hantar. Paz. ganā; the Skr. vs. only transliterate. Widely differing readings and interpretations of ~ have been proposed, v. Bthl, MirM I, 18-28; Bailey, BSOS VII, 1935, 755-759. The above interpretation, which restores the Paz. reading and respects the tradition, is due to Bailey (l. c.; ZP 20-21). I now give up my [Page81-a] interpretation in HP II, though several facts seem to favour it. -- Herzfeld's discussion of ~ (ApI 66-69) is not quite clear to me.

stench 6213. -- Cf Av. (493) ganti-; MPrth gndgyft (S), cf gndʾg ‘fetid’ (A--H III); MPrs gngyy (A-- H I); Paz. gandaī, cf gand ‘stench’, gandaa ‘fetid’; NP gand, gandā ‘anything putrid’, gandagī ‘filth’.
a demon 326-20. -- Av. (493) Gandarəwa-.
1018: read janišn, q. v.

mountain, pl. cas. obl. ~ -ān 202. -- Av. (513 sq.) gari-.
esteemed, beloved, dear, comp. ~ -tar, 225. 312. 423. 916. 164. 7318. 747. 766. -- Paz. garāmī; derived from *garām < *garamna-, middle pt. of Av. (512) 2gar-, cf āžarm and gīr-.

n. pr. 11425. -- Dial. form of Varāzak, v. varāz and Varāzān. Cat. 61. [Page81-b]
, garmōk [glmwkˡ] hot, warm 1420. 4120. 10122. -- Av. (515) garəma-, (516) garəmu- ‘heat; MPrs grmʾg ‘heat’ (A--H I); NP garm.
heat 923.
Paradise 3115 etc. passim. -- Av. (512 sq.) garō.dəmāna- ‘House of Praise’, v. garāmīk.
dust 2020.24. -- NP gard.

turning, rotation, revolution 1206.16.20. -- MPrs pres. grd- ‘to turn, to become’ (BBB), caus. grdnydn trans. ‘to turn’ (S); NP gaštan or gardīdan gard-, gardiš; etymologically not identical with vart- (v. vaštan) by which it is semasialogically influenced. hand, of demoniac beings 483-6. 6117.20. -- Borrowed from Av. (505) 4gav-.

bull, cow, with the indef. art. ~ -ē [TWRʾ + 1 458]: passim; ~ i ēvdāt (q. v.) 10418; ōišān ~ these cows, dir. obj. 426; pl. cas. obl. ~ -ān [TWRʾ-ʾnˡ] gen. 4826. 4911. 8619. 893. 9056; gen. part.: ōišān ~ -ān 2 4225; ~ -ān u gōspandān ... ēvakē vak 802-3; dir. obj. 4825-26; instead of cas. rect. 495 (gl.); -- ~ [TWRʾ] pōstihā 1079, ~ [gʾwˡ] pōstiyānihā ox-hides 11020, v. these ws. -- Last element of proper names: Bōr- ~ Gafr-, Kartār-, Nēvak-, Purr-, Ramak-, [Page82-a] Sēni-, Siyā(h)-, Spēt- ~: v. these ws. -- Av. (505 sqq.) 5gav-; MPrs gʾw (A--H I); Paz. NP gāv.
increase, growth 1099. -- From Av. (504) 1gav-, v. s. v. apazūtan; Bailey, ZP 83 sq.

the Primordial Man 4711. 633.5. 9010. 9423. 9516-21. 10524. -- Av. (503 sq.) gayō.marətan- properly ‘mortal life’; MPrs gyhmwrd (A--H I); Paz. Gayōmard; NP Gayūmart6.
snake 4011, coll. 581 (purr ~); pl. cas. rect. ~ 409.13; pl. cas. obl. ~ -ān 403. -- From BP gazītan, NP gazīdan ‘to bite, to sting’; MPrth pt. gšt (A--H III, Ghilain 99). Cf the next w.
scorpion 769. -- Also spelt gzdwm, gzdm. ‘Whose tail is stinging’: v. the preceding w. and dumb. But NP kaj-dum, kaž-dum, gaž-dum ‘having a crooked tail’, cf the next w.

a musical instrument, the horn 2010. -- Mentioned together with tumbak and nād as the musical instrument of a marching army; ‘having a curved tail, or end’ from the natural shape of an animal's horn: gāž = NP kaj, kaž ‘crooked, curved’; kāj, kāc ‘squint-eyed’.

pl. and coll., the world of creatures, men and animals, esp. the world of man: astōmandān ~ 3913; hān i mānišnōmand (q. v.) gōspandōmand ~ 5714-15; herds of grazing animals 4913; -- the material world in general: 21. 418 etc. passim. -- < *gaiθānām, gen. pl. of Av. (476 sqq.) gaēθā-; OP gaiθā- ‘live-stock’; Aram. lw. (Targ, Talm) gyty ‘herds’; MPrth gyh (< gaiθā) ‘world’, pl. gyhʾn ‘worlds’; Paz. gēhą; NP gēhān, gihān, jihān. Cf gētāh.
patron. 11425.26. -- < Vēpakān, v. Cat. 61. [Page82-b]
, gētē [gytyd6; gyty 10918] the material, corporeal world, passim. -- Borrowed from Av. gaēθā, v. gēhān; Paz. gēθī, gētī = NP.
belonging to the material world, corporeal, material 8926.

terrestrian, subst. pl. the material, terrestrian beings, cas. obl. ~ -ān [gytyk6ʾnˡ] 881.11.15. 8917. 9314. 1052; -- yazdān i gētīkān the terrestrian gods 3417 (for cas. rect., mixed constr.). -- MPrs gytyg ‘world’ (A--H II); Paz. pl. gēθyą, gēθīą, Skr. v. ihalokīyāḥ, ihacāriṇaḥ.

pres. 3d p. sg. gilēt wrongly written ʾḤDWN-ytˡ for gylytˡ, which also could be read gīrēt (from griftan): to weep, to complain 10215. -- < *girdēt < *gṛd-, SW form of girz-, v. girzītan, garzītan and grīstan; another instance of wrong ʾḤDWN- v. *gīr-. -- From *grd- also
distress 761. -- Paz. gila, Skr. v. aparādha; NP gilah ‘complaint, reproach’, cf MPrs gylgʾy ʾcomplainingʾ (S, cf s. v. cašm-kāi).

pres. 1st p. sg. gīram [ʾḤDWN-m], to praise 353. -- Written with the ideogr. of griftan gīr-, which gives no sense in this context; another vb. must be meant (cf *gil-, which is wrongly written with the same ideogr.): gīr- < *girr- < *girn-, Av. (512) 2gar-, pres. gərən-. Cf. āžarm, apažīrišnīk, garāmīk.

round 9419; ~ kartak 3824, ~ kart 3914 *fully developed (?); [spāh pat vas marak ~ kart he brought together an army of a large number KnS IV, 12 = KnA p. 229-10]. -- MPrs gyrd ‘all around’ (S), subst. ‘round’ (A--H I); Paz. NP gird; NP gird kartan ‘to collect, to assemble, to bring together’ʾ; Gūrānī gi(rd), gišt ‘all, everyone’ (KPF III, II, 248 sq.). From gart-, v. gartišn. [Page83-a]
~ pērāmōn all around 9219.
to complain, to lament 6110. -- girz- < *gṛz-, Av. (516) garəz-, pres. gərəz-; NW form; SW form gil-, grīstan, subst. gilak (v. these ws.); v. also garzītan.
grass 12813. -- MPrs gyʾw (A--H I); NP giyāh. The spelling with -b- also in FrP 6 (gbʾh); etymology ?

place, with the indef. art. ~ -ē [+ 1 or -ʾy] 713.21. 814 etc. passim; pl. cas. obl. ~ -ān 8617; as a philosophical term 312. 1098; hac an ~ paitāk from another passage it is evident (that) 4524-25, pat ~ būtan to be at the place 626-26. 71; -- apar ~ 321. 102, pat ~ 947-8 on the spot, immediately; ~ without prep. id. 144; -- ~ -ē in a place 9724; ~ ~ from place to place 9326-27, everywhere 9720; ham ~ on this very spot 1226; hamāk ~ all over 5721; visēn (q. v.) ~ in all places 9718; ē ~ to one place 9812; katām ~ whither ? where ? 75. 85. -- Inscr. and Ps. gywʾk; MPrs gyʾg; Paz. jāi, gā; NP jā; < *vivāka-, whence viyāk (q. v.).
n. pr. 474. -- BdA p. 2309 gwzk = Gūzak, but BdJ 791 Ganzak [Paz.].

cursed, epithet of Ahriman 8012. 8325. 9025; of Frāsiyāk 11318. 1163; of Alexander 1075. 11313. 1145. 1179. -- Paz. gizasta, gazista, gazasta, gijasta, gajista (Mx), gazistaa (ŠGV). Its antonym is MPrth hwjstg ‘blessed’, Ghilain 99, NP xujastah.
spokesman 579. -- V. guftan.

saying, speech, word, (the Divine) Word, command passim; pl. cas. obl. ~ -ān 6427; voice 4521; [Page83-b] the sequence mēnišn, ~, kunišn (Av. manah, vacah, šyaoθna) 6711. 1102. 1209-10, in pl. 6427; ~ burtan to say, to allege 463; ~ barišnēh kartan 3813, v. barišnēh; ~ andarg burtan to altercate 5310. -- Paz. gavešn.
det. v. n. = the preceding w.: mar ~ 437.10.12 (v. mar); passaxu ~ response 5810.20; 7015.19.21.26.

Cf BdA pp. 506--5211. 2253-5 with various corruptions of the form which also appear in 10215, v. I, 200 ad l.
(gōi) [gwd] ball 1611.12.15. -- NP gōy; cf Bailey, TPhS 1955, 73, n. 4.

1. gem, jewel 1218. 1189; adj. pat- ~ set with gems 68. -- 2. substance 4114-24. 422.10.25.27. 433.18. 787.12. 7912. 928-16. 9312. 1098; adj. pat- ~ of noble birth 698. -- MPrs. gwhr ‘substance’ (A-- H II); Paz. NP gōhar. Cf Bailey, BSOS VI, 1930, 82; ZP 83. -- V. also ham-gōhr.
species, kind 8910. -- MPrth Prs gwng; Paz. NP gūna; from Av. (482) 1gaona-.
the wild ass, with the indef. art. ~ -ē [+ 1], 318-27. 111-3; v. also Vah-²rām. -- = NP.

cattle in general, but esp. small cattle, sheep and goats, as distinguished from horses and cows, coll. 3810. 3916 etc., pl. cas. rect. 9417.20. 10416; pl. cas. obl. ~ -ān 17 [KYNʾ-ʾnˡ]. 456. 802. 8619. 893. 9056. 948. 9724. 981. 1028; -- apazār-gōspand v. apazār. -- Av. (506) gaospənta-; Paz. gōspand, NP gōspand, gōsfand.

possessing abundant cattle 5714.
ear, with the indef. art. ~ -ē [gwš + 1], 2417. 301. 3117. 671. 9525; ~ dāštan hac to take care of 148; ~ apar dāštan to care about 463-4. -- = Paz. NP; Av. (486) gaoša-, OP gauša-.

patron. of Gōtarz (Lat. Gotarzes) 11523. -- Cat. 54-55. The patron. suff. -ēn, as against common -ān, is exceptional; or -īn ?
explicit, lucid 8024-25. -- gōv- from guftan, vicār from vicārtan (q. v.): ‘word-explaining’. Paz. gaoguzār, gōguzār, gōvazār etc., Skr. v. vibhakta (Mx), suvyakta (ŠGV).

to slide, glide down: apar ~ apar ō to descend, to sink down from (a higher place) to (a lower place) 3617-21. 371.3. 4119; nē ātaxš andar urvar apar grāt the fire did not reach, and catch hold of, the plants (the fuel) 4819, with the gl. kū bē nē āyēt. -- MPrth pres. grʾy- (MHC; List 82); Av. (512) 4gar-, pres. [Page84-b] ni-grā- ‘to launch down’; cf also NP girāyistan ‘to move a th. up and down while weighing it’. -- I do not accept the reading and explanation proposed by Bailey, ZP 91 n. l.

, pres. gīr- [ʾḤDWN-], pt. = pret. pass. 3d p. sg. grift [ʾḤDWN-tˡ; glptˡ 325], to take, to seize, to catch, to take possession of 527. 613. 75.10-13.20. 821116. 910. 1010. 1615. 2221. 2417. 301. 3281120. 408. 7425; -- apar ~ 1615, frāc ~ 9823 id.; frāc ~ to embrace 4315; -- hēšm ~ to get angry 325. 154; martōmān pat kunišn gīrēnd they (the heavenly gods) call men to account for what they do 652, cf next w. -- Av. OP (526 sq.) grab-; MPrth gryftn gyrw-, Ghilain 89; MPrs gryptn gyr-, Verbum 205; Paz. griftan (pt. girift, girft) gīr-; NP giriftan gīr-. -- As to 353, v. *gīr-; as to 10215, v. gil-. -- The ideogr. ʾḤDWN coincides graphically with the ideogr. ʾB6YD-²WN-; all passages containing ʾḤDWN-²are enumerated above. -- V. also pati-²griftan.

a p. who “catches”, i. e. incurs, liability: 1. kū pat dāt i dēvān ~ nē bavē lest thou shouldst be subject to the law of the demons 6916-17; [ruvān pat mēnōyān pat kunišn aržānīkēh ~ kunēnd in the heavenly world they (the gods) call the soul to account according to the value of her deeds Mx ch. 382.6 (~ kunēnd = gīrēnd 652, v. griftan)]. -- 2. condemned to (šahrē-karān, v. s. v. kār) 92; prisoner: ~ kartan to imprison, to capture 616; [more general, to catch hold of: api-š ~ kunēt u apāc ō rāh i yazdān āvarēt Mx ch. 1523]. -- Cf NP giriftār; v. also a-griftār.
involving liability or responsiblity (opp. a-griftār) 651.

*neck-enclosure, *the head-protector of a horse in full armour, 2215. -- grī- < grīv ‘neck’ (q. v.) + kaft *enclosure, v. s. v. arašn- [Page85-a] kaft. Pagliaro's reading dar-andarzpat is unacceptable. Cf gurtēh.

griy- (BK6YWN-], pt. = pret. 3d p. grīst [glystˡ, BK6YWN-stˡ], to weep, to cry, to lament 1117. 7418.26 (Paz. substitutes here vągī¤ned6, cf vāng); bē ~ to burst out crying 1113. 341718. 511314. -- grīstan < *griy-istan formed from the pres. griy- < *grady-; *grad- SW form of garz-, v. girzītan and gil-. Ps. pt. glydyt = gliyīt, pres. glydty = griyet; MPrs pres. gryy-; NP girīstan giry-. Verbum 204 sq.
troop, company, with the indef. art. ~ -ē [~ + 1] 84. -- = Paz.; NP gurōh.

gōb- [YMLLWN-, YMR-²RWN-; 3d p. sg. gwbyt 1283, gwbytˡ 9923. 1021, gwpytˡ 2315 = gōbēt], opt. 2nd p. sg. gōbēš [YMRRWN-yš] 6012, pt. always gwptˡ = guft: to say, to tell, to utter, to pronounce, to recite, passim; with ō ‘to’, apar, rād (5311) ‘concerning, of’ (patiš 6614); followed by direct speech introduced by kū, passim; with a predicative: Hešm havand i Ahriman guft ēstet H. is said to be equal to A. 6818; 7719-20. 7913-14.16. 875-6.27 sq. 1068-9; with acc. c. inf. 11114-15; -- authoritative religious sayings are introduced by the formulas cigōn dēn gōbēt kū (36-54, passim), with hat instead of kū (387-8. 4325-26. 4414-15. 503-5), pat hān i dēn gōbēt kū (434-5), cigōn ēt i dēn gōbēt kū (5323-24 etc.), seldom andar dēn guft ēstēt kū 8011; regularly guft ēstēt is used of traditional, extracanonical sayings: 621-2. 6614. 6810. 6923. 7012. 10610-11; -- with bōžišn, passaxu and other subst., v. these; -- apāc ~ to repeat 521-22; -- apar ~ to utter loudly 4521; -- frāc ~ to pronounce 581-2; v. also pēš. -- OP gaub-; [Page85-b] MPrs gwftn gwy-; Paz. guftan, pres. 3d p. gōēd6, gōid6, gō¤end, gōind; NP guftan gūy; the typical SW vb. for saying, as against NW vac-, v. vācišnēh.
: frāc ~ possessing the faculty of speech 3824. 3912.14.

to awake, to rouse a p. from sleep 3217. -- Caus. of guhrāy- < gufrāy-, cf gwplʾdtˡ = gufrāyet rendering Av. (511) frāγrāγrāyeiti ‘rouses (him) from sleep’ Vd. 1823 and Nir. Waag p. 46 (= Sanj. fol. 27b), gwplʾdšnyh (this is the correct reading) = gufrāyišnēh rendering frāγrārayē (inf. of the same vb.), Nir. ibd; frāc gufrāyišnēh rendering Av. (977) fra-γrāti- ‘the awakening’. gu-frāy- may be explained from vi + fraγrāγrāy-, from Av. (511) 1gar-: fra-γrāγrāy- > fraγrārāy (dissimilation of γ) > fraγrāy (first haplology) > frārāy- > frāy- (second haplology); vifrāy- > gufrāy- > guhrāy-; the spelling gwhʾr- is analogous to spellings such as gwhʾl = gōhr, swhʾl = suxr, perhaps denoting a glide vowel: guhar-, gōhar, suxar. -- V. also vi-grās-.
witness, evidence 7314. 7516.17, v. next w.

witness, testifier: ~ būtan apar to bear witness to 457. -- Also gwkʾs = gukāh attested. OIr *vikāya- *‘observer’ and *‘observation’ < vi + *kāya- from Skr cāyati ‘to observe, to become aware of’; Arm. lw. (Prth) vkay; MPrth wygʾh, abstr. wygʾhyft; MPrs gwgʾy, abstr. gwgʾyy; Ps. abstr. gwkʾdyhy = gukāyēh(ē); Paz. guvāh, guvāī, NP guvāh guvāhī or guvāʾī (Paz. NP < *guγāi); Av. (1436) vīkaya- FrO VIII, a spotlessly authentic Av. w., as shown by vī and by the shortening of -āya- to -ay(y)a- regular in Av. The alternation -āi: -āh (spelt -ʾs in BP) as usual in MiIr, cf s. v. cašm-kāi, whose last element is etymologically identical with -kāi in gukāi. Earlier discussions: Schaeder, UJ XV, 1936, 567 sq.; Benveniste, JA 228, [Page86-a] 1936, 225 sq. (because of Av. vīkaya-, Sogd wcʾw ‘witness’ cannot be compared). Henning, Weller Vol. p. 297, combines Av. vīkaya- with Sogd. wcʾw, deriving the Av. form from *vikāu‡ya- with assimilation of -u‡y- to -yy- and then shorttening of -ā- > -ă-. However, -u‡y- is not assimilated in Av.: zaoya-, haoya-, hvaŋ-²haoya-, kaoya-, gaoya-, aδaoya-, mainyao-²ya- (v. mēnōi), kąsaoya-, snāuya-.
pres. to destroy 9026 (Paz. substitutes vānom, v. vānītan). -- Av. (438) vi-2kan- = OP; MPrth w(y)gʾ-²nyšn, Ghilain 71; MPrs pres gwgʾn-, v. n. gwgʾnyšn, Verbum 189. V. s. v. kandan.
to bear witness, pt. = pret. pass. 3d p. sg. +gukāyīt [+gwkʾdtˡ] 5013. -- Cf Arm. lw. vkay-em.
flower 216. -- Av. (1369) varəδa-; Arm. lw. vard ‘rose’ as Aram. (Syr. etc.) lw. wrdʾ, Arab ward; MPrth wʾr ‘flower’ (A--H III), NP gul ‘rose,; flower’.
patron. of *Gulaxš < Valaxš (q. v.) 11714.
doubt: ~ kartan pat to doubt 1074; ~ būtan pat to be doubtful of 1082. -- = NP; MPrs. gwmʾn, v. Sogd. 42; Paz. gumą. -- V. a-gumān, apē-gumān.
scepticism, unbelief 1083.
pt. of next w., coll. the staff of Royal commissioners 15. -- Another interpretation by Pagliaro, RSO XXIII, 1948, 67.

entry.sense: to be, only in the pres. ind., subju. and opt., other forms from būtan (q. v.): 1. as an independent vb. in the 3d p.: exist(s), e. g. hast hān kē ahlāyēh the One who is Righteousness exists 573; hēc kē būt hēnd u hēc kē bavēnd u hēc kē hēnd all who have been, and all who will be, and all who exist (now) 6417-18, cf subst. hast and nēstēh; im rōc 7 māhakān hast tāi ... to-day it is seven months since 1011-12; kē hast kē ...? who is there who ...? 257.27; andar Ērān-šahr asvār-ē nēst kē ... in Eran-shahr there is no horseman who ... 1515; hast i-š ... u hast i-š ... u hast i ... there is some (of it) that ... and there is some (of it) ... and there is some (of it) that ... = part of it ... part of it ... etc. 9317-18.26; hast kē-š vēš, hast kē-š kam some have more, others less 966; astōmandān mar-²tōmān (gen. part.) hast i ... of earthly men there are some who 10516; hast <i> šāhān šāh, hast <i> kēsar some belong to the King of Kings, others to the Emperor 11519-20; nē hast kū there is no place where, nowhere 6113; hast (i) ka there is a time when, sometimes, at times 7725-26. 8122. 12018-19; -- with prev.: šusr i Gayōmart ciš andar hast there is some part of the sperm of G. in it 9422-23; kū-š ātaxš andar nēst where there is no fire 3721. -- 2. copula, with a noun, a pron., or a prep. + subst. as its complement, pas-²sim; the 3d p. sg. ‘is’ is very often not [Page87-b] expressed (nominal sentence as in the Semitic languages): man Šāhpuhr hom 1514; tō kē hē ? 732; tō rād kē Dugdāv hē 4721; ēn rētak kē hast ? who is this boy ? 1617; Artaxšēr ... nē pat giyāk hast 627 sq.; kē zan-ē hac ōi hucihrtar nēst ‘qua pulchrior non est mulier’, who is the most beautiful of all women 259-10; ōišān amāh hēm kē ... we are of those who 5723-24; šmāh kē xiōn hēt 6111; sagr hēnd 8622. -- 3. in the 3d p., together with a subst. virtually in dat., or with a pron. in cas. obl., it expresses ‘to possess’ xānak i-t hast the house that belongs to thee 5325-26; fradandān i-š hast the children he has 142; with rād as in NP: Pāpak rād pus-ē hast 32. -- 4. Together with verbal or other nouns it forms periphrastic verbal expressions, e. g. han-²dēšītār vicītār hom 125; frēftār hāh 3419; matār hom 467; kartār hom 10127; brihēnāk hēnd 7722; kē (cas. obl.) vitīrišn nēst which is incorruptible 669; tō hān-ic ākāh hē this thou knowest 396; hayyār hēnd they help 1066; -š hayyārēh hēnd they help him 10011-12; pat hamēstārēh i spihr hēnd they offer resistance to the Sphere 8721; kē (cas. obl.) Mihr u Māh pat pušt hāh which M. and M. protect 317-8, etc. -- 5. auxiliary vb. forming compound tenses: būt hom, būt hēnd I was, they were, etc., v. Grammar; notice: HWH-nd, regularly hēnd, must stand for the subju. hānd 142 (fut.). 335 (cond.). -- 6. Wrong use of the ideogr. ḤWH-: a) ḤWH-wm for the encl. pron. 1st p. sg., added to the pret. pass. in order to emphasize the agent- [Page88-a] pron. already mentioned before the vb.: man kart ḤWH-wm = man kart-om by me it was done 324 (twice); api-m ... hamē tacīt ḤWH-wm = tacīt-om 3119, v. s. v. tacitan; -- b) āyēnd ḤWH-yd6 = āyēnd-ē 611, v. s. v. 4ē; -- c) ḤWH-m = adj. and adv. ham (q. v.); ḤWHw-ytˡ = pron. ēt (v. ē, ēt). -- The Prth forms v. I, 175; one such form in the BP text: ʾdyh = ayēh 2718, MPrth ʾyy. -- OP Av. (266 sqq.) 1ah-.

prep., with -c: MN-c = hac-ic; not with an encl. pron. (as to haciš, hacišān v. s. v. haciš); the original sense ‘accompanying, with’ (Skr sacā) is still transparent in ~ ... hāmist (q. v.) ‘together with’, but the meaning ‘from, of’ prevails since the OIr period. 1. Local: hān yām ... hac dast i Artaxšer ō damīk ōpast 926; api-š hēcak hac cāh ul hixt 158; hakar hac asp bē nišīnam 272; hac star pādak tāi mah pādak 937; hac dar ōišān bagān namāc burt from the gate-way (i. e., halting at the entrance, from this place) I rendered adoration to His Majesty. P 1:4; -- figurative, with a great many vbs. and idioms, the sense of ‘from, of’ being more or less transparent. ākāhē-²nītan, āšnūtan, pursītan, xuāstan, dast šustan hac etc., v. the individual ws.; -- origin: kē cihr (Prth šihr) hac yazatān (Prth yʾztn) whose origin is from the gods, of divine origin HajB: 2.4 (HajA: 2.4). ŠPrs: 5-6 (yazdān) (ŠPrth: 5). P 1: 2.4 (yazdān); *Apasāi ... i hac Harān ŠPrs: 9; hac tōhmak i Dārāi būt 18, etc. -- 2. temporal: hac im rōc from today onwards, henceforth 97; hac im rōc tāi 3 rōc within three days 516; hac rahīkēhy [lsykyhy] ever since my youth 12826; etc. -- 3. after a. v. n. it expresses the subj. of the act: patīrak zanišn i hac ganāk mēnōi on the point of being slain by the Evil Spirit 465-6; zanišn i dēvān hac hān i ōi xuarrah the demons being slain by his divine splendour 4612; frēftakēh i hac dēvān deception by the demons 461; 4513-14; etc. -- [Page88-b] 4. partitive: hac fradandān i hān mart kasē anyone of the children of that man 25; hac šmāh xiōnān kē hast kē ...? 257 etc.; fratom hac axu i astōmand 5317; xuaštom hac xuarišnān the most delicious of dishes 7413; etc. -- 5. in comparison ‘than’: hac apārīk kanīcakān āžarmīktar 422; Zarristan kē ... zan-ē hac ōi hucihr-²tar nēst 259-10; hac tō vēh 411; kū-š sūk mas būt hac apārīk gāv 492-3; more emphatically yuvattar (q. v.) hac hān i huhōmīkān hōmtar 4027. -- 6. causative: hac hān dušxuār sahist by this he was very much shocked 42-3; hac hān i dēvān sārēnišn 3724-25; causal conj.: hac hān cigōn because 4511; hac hān i with a nominal clause 481. -- 7. forming adverbs: hac pas, hac pēš, hac bē, hac apar (hacapar), hacadar; prepositions: pas hac, pēš hac (= patiš hac 368), yuvat hac, bē hac; frame prepositions: hac ... rād owing to 1525-26; hac ... bērōn 2023; hac ... yuvatāk 766. -- Av. (1746 sqq.) hacā¤; OP hacā; MPrth ʾc, ʾž; MPrs ʾc, ʾz; Paz. ež (eži-ca); NP az.

A secondary enlargement of MPrs hmys = hamis ‘together with’ (A--H II) or ʾc ... hmys (S), < OP *hami¢a- (hami¢iya- ‘rebellious, rebel’), NW *hamiθra-, *-riya-, whence MPrth (BBB) hmyr < *hamihr ‘in all, all told’. Pagliaro, RSO XIX, 1941, 283 sq., Jackson Vol., 1954, 102-110; Nyberg, Unvala Vol., 1964, 102 sq.
adv.: ~ kart brought together 11219.
fellow-worker, partner 707.

the quality, or state, of being of the same form, or shape, as another: pat ~ i amahraspan-²dān as being of the same shape as the Amahraspands 3826, with the gl. kū ētōn būt cigōn amahraspand-ē. -- V. karp.
co-operation 5718.
of the same religion, co-religionist 193.6.18.
having the same (religious) virtues as another 6418.
the act of co-operating 10619.
having hair of the same colour 12025 (read MNW hm mwd). -- V. mōd.

of every kind, all, whole, subst., and adj. placed before its subst., but after a pron.: hac ōišān ~ 316; passim; adv. in short, brief 1111. -- *hāma- (v. hāmist) + abdēn > audēn > ōdēn, NW form corresponding to SW āivēnak (q. v.); thus a synonym of ham-āivēnak (q. v.). Paz. hamōīn. The scribes write and read admodin = hdmwdyn = hēmōdēn; I have throughout corrected this form to hʾmw-² = hāmō-, but perhaps hēmō- is an authentic form, cf MPrth hynzʾwr ‘powerful’ (A--H III and, with correct explanation, BBB) = henzāvar < *ham-zāvar. [Page93-a]
level ground, a plain: pat hān dašt i ~ 1922, cf NP dašt u hāmūn. -- < *hāma-van-.
silent; ~ būtan to become silent, to cease speaking 3423. -- NP xāmōš.

deliberation, consultation, conference, dialogue, esp. of the meetings of Zartuxšt and his apocalyptic sons with Ohurmazd and the revelations received by them on these occasions: 4714. 514. 5424. 5717. 968-10. 989. 9910.12; in another context ~ kartan 10619. -- ŠGV IV, 6 hampursaī. Skr, v. anyonya-praśnatā.
adj.: magūnē ~ xrat the wisdom (understanding) of the Magi won through consultation (of the gods) 11215.
to consult, to deliberate, to plan: hān murv (pl. cas. rect.) hampursīt hēnd kū ... 404-5. -- V. pursītan.
an equal 685. -- Skr v. samāna. V. tāk.
of the same family, related, akin 99. 7026.
having debts in common with another, jointly responsible for a debt (debts) 707. -- Paz. hamθōjī; from tōxtan.
side by side with: api-²šān *sīh-ē (v. 2sīh) ~ hamē raft and a *splendour ran constantly at their side 724. -- ham + var, cf yāvar.

always, continually 17. 135. 12117. -- Paz. ham(a)vār, hamjār. A synonym of hambār (q. v.) with which it is generally regarded to be identical (OP *hama-bāra- > hamvār) and then remodelled after the simple bār); but perhaps better connected with Skr vāra- ‘turn, time’, cf Av. (1362 sq.) 3var- ‘to turn’.
the act of drinking together: api-š mad pat ~ ō [Page93-b] ham xuart 6118; as to the construction v. s. v. pat.

, with emphasizing particle hān-ic [ZK-c; on ZK-p, ZK-py 5113.15 v. s. v. -p], dem. pron., sg. and pl., referring to what is distant from the speaker, or already mentioned; independent, or adj. placed before its headw. (exception: viyāk hān HajB: 9); the adj. hān may be replaced by hān i, properly ‘that which is’: hān i *sīh that *splendour 725-26; hān i Vīdrafš i yātūk 2513; hān i yāmak 5716; esp. if -c is added to it: hān-ic i dar-band 244; hān-ic i Hutōs 2422; -- determinative: hān i ..., hān ... i ..., hān kē, hān cē (364), har hān kē, hān kas kē, hān katārcihē kē, hān and cand; -- ham cand hān, v. ham; -- sometimes referring back to the rel. pron.: i hac hān nēvakōktar būtan nē šāyist quo pulchrius esse non poterat, the most beautiful imaginable 718-19; -- emphasizing the interrog. kē: kē hān hē ? who art thou, say ! 5619, cf Syr mannū < man-hū, Arab man d6ā, mā d6ā. -- hān i regularly introduces the definite rel. attr. (v. s. v. i; less often ēn i, ēt i, ōi i): hān i xuēš xuatāi 518; hān i pit framān 3727 sq.; hān i anagr rōšnēh 3618; hān i dēvān sārēnišn 3724-25 (NB: in this case not -išnēh, but without hān i it would be dēvān sārēnišnēh !); -- replaces a subst. already mentioned: hīr i mēnōi ... hān i gētāh the property of the heavenly world ... that of the material world 798; ruvān hān i kē ? whose soul ? answer: hān i Kri-²šāsp 312-4; -- elliptic expressions: hān i man my religious duty 539 (referring to what is already mentioned in 1. 5, cf s. v. ēn), the full expression 1. 7-9: nē hān i man apāyet yaštan ēt (this man here) frāc yazēt; andar hān i man in my house 3717-18; similarly 3618-20. 371; -- hān i governs a nominal clause: hac hān i Zartuxšt andar hān xuarrah because Z. was (in =) endowed with such a glory 481. -- hān occurs in a great many compound [Page94-a] adverbs and conjunctions: hac hān frāc, hac hān pas, pas hac hān, pat hān (cf s. v. pattān), andar hān; hac hān cigōn, hac hān i ka, pas hac hān i ka, tāi hān i ka, etc. -- hān i cigōn ēn thus 438. -- Exclusively Prs: MPrs hʾn, pl. hʾnyšʾn; Paz. ą; NP ān; possibly contracted of *hāu-an(y)a-, Av. (1730 sq.) hāu (but OP hauv), cf s. v. an, anē. NB: -- Through confusion with the ideogr. ʾḤRN = an which coincides graphically with hʾnˡ = hān, ZK is often misused as an ideogr. for an, and, with the complement -ʾy: ZK-ʾy, for anē, v. s. v. an, anē, where the instances are enumerated. -- ZK is also used for han in han-tāi.
storehouse, larder 973-6.9.10. -- MPrth ʾmbʾrg; Arm. lw. (h)ambar, Talm. ʾmbrʾ, NP anbār; v. Telegdi 229.

the act of flowing together, confluence: ~ i āp andar zrāi i Pūtīk 869-10. -- Paz. anbārašn; < ham + Av. (851) 4par- ‘to pass over, or through’, caus. *pārayeiti ‘to let through’. The Skr. v. saṃhati is based on NP an-²bāštan, anbārdan ‘to fill’, from Av. (850) 2par-.
to accuse, to charge with: pat yātūkēh ~ 3714. -- Den. of hanbasān, Paz. anbasą- ‘contradictory’, abstr. -ānī (ŠGV); MPrs ʾmbsʾn ‘calumniator’ (Sogd. 52. 53); Arm. lw. ambastan ‘accuser’.
measure; ~ nimūtan to measure 1106. -- From handāxtan (q. v.); NP andāzah; Talm. lw. hndzʾ ‘calculation’; Syr. lw. handāzā ‘that which is measured’.
the act of measuring; andar ... ~ i ō collating with 1123.
counsel, advice 419. 62 (heading). -- Ps. hndlcy ‘command, law’; MPrs ʾndrz (S); NP andarz. [Page94-b]
to give directions, warnings, to instruct: api-m xūpihā ... handarzēnīt hē 7615-16.

chancellor, chief judge, head of the treasury of a province or a corporation, administrator of property: Sakistān ~ P 1:6; dar- ~ i vās-²puhrakān the court administrator of the (royal) properties 1118-19, v. 2vāspuhrakān and Pe4rikhanian, RE4A V, 1968, 20-21 (cf s. v. vāspuhr); [yʾztpt MLKTH-n hndrzpty KZŠPrth 1. 27 = yʾztpt ZY bʾny(!)kn hndlcpt Prs 1. 33 = Gr. v. (enumerated among the lower ranks of court officials)]. -- Arm lw. handerjapet ‘the Master of the Royal household’, already in the Bible (e. g. 1 Kings 16:9 = Gr ), then often ‘director, manager’ in different functions; when speaking of Persian officials the authors use the form anderjapet: Sakstan a. Pʾaust. Buz. 4, 45, mogac2 a. ‘the chancellor of the Magiʾ ibd. 4, 47, or in the idiomatic Persian form Movan a. El£iše (5th c.), Hist. of the Vardans (Venedig 1838), 138. 142 (thus the MSS; the ed. han-).

handāc- 1. apāc ~ to bring together again, to reunite, with apāk ‘with’: apāk apastāk apāc handāxt reunited (them) with the Avesta 10911. 11119-20. -- 2. to measure, to calculate (the horoscope) 76. -- 3. impers.: api-m ... cigōn ul ō hān hōm nē handācēt and as I [standing on the ground] do not reach up to that haoma [placed at the top of the tree] 4026. -- Ps. ʾndʾhtny, ʾndʾc- ‘to judge’; MPrs pres. ʾndʾc-, Verbum 186; Paz. NP andāxtan andāz-. -- V. handā-²cišn, handācak.
: apāc ~ i ō the act of bringing back to 11216.
apprehension, anxiety 96.
to think, to reflect, to ponder 918. 118. 139. -- MPrs [Page95-a] ʾndyšydn (S); MPrth ʾndyšʾdn (A--H III); NP andēšīdan.
one who thinks, reflects, ponders 125 (kū). 137 (apar), v. s. v. h-, no. 4.
anxiety, anguish 1116. -- NP andōh; v. Sogd 1720. 20.
anxious 49. -- Also handōhakēn, J.-Prs ʾndwhgyn Isa 1:2. Arm. lw. andohakan ‘disquieting, dreadful’.

*discouraged: dil ~ kart it made his heart *discouraged 73; [adv. -ihā: ōišān vas ~ -ihā ō Artaxšēr guft very discouraged they said to A. KnS VII, 3]. -- Reading uncertain; no Paz. known to me. Henning, followed by M. Schwartz (JRAS 1966, 121), reads hangrū-²tak, connecting it with MPrs grwdg ‘lamentation’, grwdgyn ‘lamenting’ (List 83, with another reading of our passage 73). However, the idea of ‘lamentation’ is scarcely to the point in the quoted passages (it would be important to know more about the use and purport of grwdg). Until further elucidation I maintain my old reading *handrūtak, now connecting it with drūtan drav-, commonly ‘to mow, to reap’, but originally ‘to cut’, thus han-drūtak ‘cut up, afflicted’. Bailey, BSOAS XXIV, 1961, 478, discusses a root drav-, dru- ‘to treat violently’, which is perhaps identical.
time, epoch, season 226. 1420. 613. -- MPrs ʾngʾm (S); Paz. hangąm; NP hangām. -- Cf āvām.
computation 887. -- Paz. angāra; NP angārah ‘a revenue book’. From

1. to perform: spās, spāsdārēh ~ andar to offer thanks [Page95-b] unto (God) 1222-23. 172. -- 2. to calculate, to determine 917. -- 3. to consider, to bear in mind 413. 725. -- Paz. angārdan; MPrs hngʾr-, subst. ʾngʾr (S) ‘to regard as, to consider as’; NP angāštan (also BP), angārīdan ‘to think, to consider’. Av. (447) han-kārayeiti, from ham + caus. of 2kar-; cf s. v. 2kartan and hangirtīkēh.

welfare, prosperity, fortune 693. -- Paz. angidī, Skr v. ṛddhitva; MPrth ʾngd ‘happy, rich’, hwʾngd ‘rich in fortune’; ʾngdg ‘perfect, prosperous’ (BBB); Av. hangata- ‘entire, complete’ Vd. 29.13.17 (Henning), against AirWb 3807).

instigator: anākēh ~, of Ahriman 6715. -- For hangēxtār with the change of preconsonantic -ēh-, -ēx- to -ah-, -ax- often observed in MiPrs, cf s. v. mahmānēh. From hangēxtan hangēž- ‘to exite, to provoke, to rouse’ (vāt hangēžēt [hngycytˡ] ‘provokes flatulence’ GF II, 31); NP angēxtan, angēzīdan; Paz. husažihed6 wrong transliteration of han-²gēžihēt ‘is produced, excited’ (ŠGV VII, 18. XVI, 32). Hence
: ul ~ to raise from the dead, imp. sg. 9827; pres. 3d p. sg. -ēnēt 97. 10015.17-18. 1014.23. -- NP angēzānīdan. As to the reading v. Crit. App. ad 10015.
to bring together so as to form one whole; hangir-²tēnīt comprehensive 1047. -- Den. of hangirt, v.the next w.

: in all probability the same predicative form of hangirtīk (adj.) as Prth. ākasī (q. v.) of ākas: ~ būt (cancel the following <i>) ... andar 2 pit were combined, united in the parents 433-4, cf s. v. būtan no. 4. -- hangirtīk, Paz. angirdī ‘compendious’, Skr v. parimita (ŠGV), from hangirt, Paz. angird ‘summary’, also enlarged to angirdī (< -ēh) -- all going back to OIr *han-kṛti-, Av. (1770) han-kərəti-, rendered in Phl by [Page96-a] hangirtīkēh, the abstr. n. of hangirtīk; from ham + 1kartan (q. v.). The Paz. forms show that hangirt-, not *hangart-, is the correct reading.

*resolute, *decided 4822. 498.22. 5014. -- Both reading and meaning unknown to me. Tentatively I connect it with NP hang which, inter alia, means ‘will, purpose’. Another possibility would be to connect it with MPrs hnng ‘*aversion’, List 80. 83.

resemblance; representation; reflection (of light) 1117.21. 1124; a symbol 12021.22; -- in comparisons, together with homānāk: pūt ~ homānāk (food) resembling putrid matters 7612-13; damīk andar miyān i asmān ~ ētōn homānāk cigōn ... the resemblance of the earth in the centre of the heaven is like ... = the position of the earth ... resembles 865. -- From ham + gōš, cf NP gōšah ‘angle, corner, edge’: ‘having the same angle or edge’, ‘bordering on’. MPrs ʾngwšydg; Paz. angōšīdaa (ŠGV), Skr. v. dṛṣṭānta ‘pattern, model’, upa-²māna ‘comparison’, nidarśana, pratirūpa ‘example’. A good illustration of its use and purport ŠGV V, 15-16.
v. hixtan.

pres. st. of hanjāftan ‘to complete, to accomplish, to carry out, to carry to an end’, in composition: kā-²mak- ~ forcing his will upon (apar) another 518. -- MPrs hnzʾftn hnzʾm-, caus. of hnzftn ‘to come to an end’, Verbum 190 sq.; MPrth hnjftn hnjʾm- ‘to bring to an end’, Ghilain 72 sq.; Paz. anžāmešn ‘termination, end’, Skr. v. pariṇāma (Mx), anjāmī id., Skr. v. paripāka (ŠGV); from Av. (501) ham + gam-. OP ham + gam- ‘to assemble’, v. the next w.
meeting, assembly, congregation 4214. 6618. 7022. 916. 10323. --Av. (1770) hanjamana-; MPrth hnjmn; MPrs hnznm (A--H I); NP anjuman; Ps. ‘ncwmnyh'y ‘congregations’. [Page96-b]
to speak in the assembly, Lat contionari, 619.
who speaks in the assemblies, orator, eloquent, epithet of Nērōsang 6010, renders Av. (1477) vyāxana-.
limb, member, pl. cas. obl. ~ -ān 897. -- SW form, with -nn- < -nd-, of NW handām: MPrth hndʾm, MPrs hnʾm (A--H I); Paz. NP NW form andām.

until, on to: ~ ō miyān van to the middle of the tree 415; ~ hān i vēh Dāitī 564; pēš hac ~ ka-mān ... jōyāt before he devours us 986-7 (as to mān, v. s. v. man). -- OIr *anu-tāvat ‘towards as far (as)’, cf Skr tāvat ‘so long, so far’ (yāvat ‘as’), v. tāi; hence MiIr *(h)an-tāv, SW han-tāi, later *(h)andāi, Paz. andā. Prth han < anu, KZŠPrth 1. 2 hn prhš ʾL = han fraxš ō, Gr , also han ō ibd. and 1. 19 = Prs 1. 24 ʾD = tāi, Gr . Not found in MPrthPrs -- Av. (127) anu, OP anuv.

every, each, all; together with the indef. art. each: ~ gām-ē at each step 3217; 8725. 949; ~ ēvak each one 1045-6. 11318; ~ 2 both, passim; ~ kas, ~ kasē everyone, ~ ciš everything; ~ kē, ~ cē, v. these ws.; pat ~ 40 sāl each fortieth year 8622; in neg. sentence: any 619. 10010; whatever 8212. -- = Paz. NP; MPrthPrs hrw = harv; Av. (1790) haurva-, OP haruva. V. also harvēn, har-²visp, harvist, harvistēn.
, Harāk [hlʾk] Herat 3727. 1145. -- Av. (1787) harōiva-, OP haraiva-; KZŠPrth 1. 2 hryw. The authentic form is Harāi; Harāk has received an inorganic -k which seems to be merely orthographic.

n. pr. of a town ŠPrs: 9. -- According to Christensen (apud Ghirshman) in the neighbourhood of Isfahan (I only find Arān or Ārān, Ibn Rosteh 1541, of which Awām, Ibn Khordadbeh 2012, seems to be a corruption). [Page97-a]
the mountain chain surrounding this world 8611. 8713. 89. 93 passim. -- Av. (1788) Harā bərəzaitī, NP Alburz.

*hārēf-; [hʾlyp-] 1. to mix, referring to the coition 4315: after ēvak apar, apāk dit, apar ēstāt hēnd ō ēn kār 4314-15 (v. 2apāk 2) the narrator continues api-šān MDM hārēft: as the construction is pass. we expect here a subj.; this is probably hidden in MDM which is, in that case, the wrong ideogr. for a w. ʾpl = ʾpr or ʾcl = ʾcr, or the like, signifying ‘the genital fluid’: the fluids from their genital organs were mixed together, with the gl. kū-šān pat +ākōš (q. v.) frāc grift ‘that is: they clasped tightly’. -- 2. to infect: api-š ōi dīt Zartuxšt pas andarg haxt ka hārēft ēstāt purr gaz (etc.) and Z. saw her from behind, between her thighs, (and saw) that they were infected, full of snakes (etc.) 5726--581. -- 3. to attach, to assign a th. to (ō) a p,: whenever Pourušāsp desires to have a divine service performed yazišn ō yaš-²tārān hārēfāt he shall assign the service to (true) ministrants 5314-15, with the gl. kū ō yazāt kē apāyet yaštan ʾthat is: that one shall perform the divine service to whom it pertains to perform such service’, cf s. v. bahr. -- From Av. (1483) hąm.raēθwayeiti ‘to mix, to mingle, to infect’, from which the signification ‘to attach’ was easily derived (cf the simplex vb. in the expression kəhrpəm raēθwayeiti ‘assumes a visible shape’ Yt. 813); a den. of raēθwa- ‘mixture, muddle’. *ham-ra- > hąra-, cf (1529) rąrəma- < *ramrama- (the Av. spelling hąm- is a compromise between hą- and ham-); *hąr- in MiIr > hār-. The MiIr vb. belongs to the NW linguistic area: raēθw-²> rēf- is a normal NW development. As the vb. is a den., the pres. st. hārēf- must be regarded as the primordial form, and [Page97-b] the inf. hārēftan as a secondary formation based on it.
one of the Amahras-²pands 3910. 6910. the name of the 3d month of the year 9715. -- Av. (1791) haurvatāt-; MPrth hrwdʾd Sogd. 19; Paz. Averdād6; NP Xurdād.

attributive form of har < harv; ~ kas everyone 6410; v. also harvistēn. -- In Bal. (NW language) an adj. precedes its noun and generally takes the ending -ēn (-eÇ), Longworth Dames, TBL 13 (Gilbertson did not hear the final nasal, BL 35, obs. 2). Cf nēvakēn and v. s. v. mēnōi.
all, every 3718. 417 etc. passim. -- < har + visp (q. v.).
“all-malignancy”, the basic character of Ahriman 641.
all 7922; whole 5211. 7720. -- Sup. of har < harv; cf hā¤mist.
the attributive form of harvist 467.8 (v. matār). 885.7. -- V. s. v. harvēn.

early, in the beginning: ~ hac apārīk xuarišn before the other food 922; [~ -am i pat bun nipišt kū ... previously, in the fundamental chapter, I wrote ... BdA p. 4115 (Henning, JRAS 1942, 241, n. 1 not acceptable)]. -- NW w., also hasē, adj. hasēnak (MPrth hsyng); SW ahē, adj. ahēnak (MPrs ʾhyng): Nyberg, Henning Vol. 343-348.

wine: xuaštom hac xuarišnān, ~ mēnōyān yazdān: ~ hān i maiδyōzarm rōvan the most delicious of dishes (or, beverages), to wit: the wine of the heavenly gods -- “wine”: that is the midspring ghee 7413-14 (rōvan = rōgn, q. v.). -- KZŠPrs 1. 25 hs = Prth 1. 20 ḤMR; ibd. Prth 1. 24 mdydr = madē-dār, Prs 1. 30 [hs]dʾly = has-dāry (the restoration almost certain) ‘butler’; hence it follows that mad was the NW w., has the SW [Page98-a] w. for ‘wine’. V. further s. v. mad. -- The ideogr. is borrowed from the homonym 1has. -- Neriosengh had no inkling either of 1has or 2has; in 7413-14 he omitted the first KZY and rendered the second by haē, translating it in Skr śīghram ‘quickly’. -- V. Nyberg, Henning Vol. p. 345.
one moment, one minute 663. -- Borrowed from Av. (1802 sq.) hāθra- which signifies both the measure of a distance (of varying length) and the shortest unit of time.
1. pres. 3d p. sg. of h-, q. v. -- 2. as subst. pl. hastān those who exist 578; 5518 v. bavētān. -- 3. abstr. subst. existence, mode of existence 312. 4218; frāc hac ~ raft he disappeared 5011.

1. abstr. of hast 2: pat ~ hamē būtēh hamē bavētēh in the quality of existing, of always having existed and destined always to exist 636, v. bavētān. -- 2. the quality of having existence, reality 8418.
possessing real existence 5627. 571.
eight.
eighteenth.
eighth.

1. pres. subju. 3d p. sg. of h-: andar gāv pēm gumēxt ~ so that it may be mixed with the milk of the cows 423-4; modal: would seem to be 389. -- 2. ‘it shall be’ used as an adv. in order to introduce a quotation from a sacred text = to wit, namely: cigōn dēn gōbēt ~ 388. 4326. 4415. 505; 1113. -- 3. perf. pass. cigōn nūn kušt hat 981-2. A parallel form of hāt; Paz. hat, Skr v. syāt (ŠGV). -- V. Grammar 7. 7.
Notes on the Persepolis inscriptions pp. 126-127, dealt with by Richard N. Frye, AO XXX, 1966, pp. 83-93.
I. L. 1: it is doubtful whether the bulges visible to the left of the two perpendicular strokes denoting 121 are due to the cutter. [Page98-b] More probably they are small involuntary breaks caused by the cutting. -- L. 3: on the reading v. s. v. Tūrān.
II. L. 1: the first figure is absolutely clear 20; it never means 10, the form of which is well known and quite different, v. MP I, 173. Then there is a slight break, through which remnants of a second figure 20 are faintly visible; then it follows, quite clearly, again the figure 20. The number is beyond doubt 68. -- L. 7-8: I think I can warrant the correct reading (7) ... KBYR (8) ṬB, after my close examination of the inscription in 1971, v. s. v. nēv. The letter /Ṭ/ is slightly damaged, but the characteristic top is unmistakable.
the name of the second section of the Avesta 9614. -- Av. (1758) haδa.mąθra-, cf dātīkēh and gahānīk.
belonging to hāt-mānsr 9614.

equal (to) 5825. 6818. -- Av. (174 sq.) avant- ‘so great, so much, as great as ...’; Paz. havand; KZŠPrth 1. 3. 16. 17 ʾwnt, Prs equivalent (only 1. 21 = Prth 1. 16) uncertain (ʾwndy ?), Gr. v. ; MPrth ʾʾwyndg ‘equal’ (MHC); MPrs hʾwnd, hʾwynd ‘similar’ (A--H II). Cf s. v. and.
equivalence; expiation 4525.
disciple, priestly novice 1116. -- Av. (1806) hāvišta-; FrP 13 explained by magū (mōg) ‘member of the class of Magi’. Bailey, JRAS 1953, 97.
thigh 5726. -- Av. (1745) haxt-.
to pull: api-m ... carm bē haxt and I stripped off his skin 3211-12. -- Av. (784 sq.) θang-. The pres. āhanj- (q. v.) and hanj- (v. hixtan) belong to this root.

*down there: ~ +ā¤varēm [ʾŠTHn-ym = hwlym: xua-²rēm, wrong reading of ʾwlym] let us go down there, descend (to the plain mentioned immediately after) 1920. -- The text of the MSS: ʾnwš ʾŠTHn-ym = anōš xuarēm is void of sense here (anōš-²xuar ‘enjoying immortality’ Phl Vd. [Page101-b] 1931). Any emendation of it is fruitless as long as xuartan is in the case. The only solution of the riddle lies in substituting ʾwlym: ā¤varēm (v. s. v. avar) for hwlym. Accordingly the preceding w. must be an adv. No adv. with this form is thus far known, but I venture to introduce it here: +hwnyh = hōnēh < *avanay-ā, loc. of *avana- ‘low, situated downwards’, another adverbial form of which is found in the Arm. lw. xonarh < *(h)avanaθra, i x. ‘downwards’, x. also secondarily used as adj. ‘humble, base, mean’. Parallel with *avana- is avara- (v. avar, ōrōn, hu-²ōrōn, ōristar), borrowed in Arm as xor ‘deep’ < *(h)avara-, pl. xor-kʾ ‘abyss’; avara- is to *avana- what Av. (76 sq.) apara- is to (75) apana-. I leave it to the experts of Sogd to decide whether the Sogd. dem. pron. γwnʾk, Christ. Sogd xwnyy might have anything to do with our *hōn-. -- As to the form, cf pasēh, pēšēh.

“of good swing”, epithet of the varz ‘mace’ (v. vazr) carried by Keresāspa 1003. -- Renders Av. (1832) hu-nivixta- ‘well swung’, epithet of the vazra- of Mithra (Yt. 65. 10132) and of the vazra- in general (Yt. 1040. 1372); < ni + vaēg-, v. s. v. 2vēxtan. Reading hypothetical, no Paz. reading being known to me. I take it as *hu-vēxm < *hu-vaixman- from 2vēxtan < vaig- (q. v.), which has been largely confounded with 1vēxtan < vaik-; *huvēxm > hu-vaxm (or perhaps better *hu-vahm) cf s. v. mahmān. As to vēxtan as a battle term cf 254. -- As Bthl (Wb 1832) has given quite misleading information about the Phl. w. I put here the notice he quotes in its correct form. It is found in the Phl Xuaršēt niyāyišn (= Yt 6) in Zand-i Khūrtak Avistāk ed. by Dhabhar, p. 21 § 15: kē yašt Ohur-²mazd i amarg ... api-š yašt Mihr i frāgōyōt ... (1. 14) api-š yašt vazr i *hu-²vaxm/pat kamār apar i dēvān/i Mihr frāgōyōt (ē: *huvaxmēh ē kū bāstān ētōn dārēt: mēnōyihā bē šavēt, vināskārān pātifrās bē kunēt, u mēnōyihā apāc ō kantīr āyēt) ‘he who has worshipped Ohurmazd the Immortal ... has (at the same time) worshipped Mihr (the god) of wide pasturages ... (1. 14) and he has worshipped the mace of good swing on the skulls of the devs, owned by Mihr of wide pasturages (its being “of good swing” means that it constantly behaves in the following manner: spiritually it goes off and punishes the sinners, and spiritually it returns to the quiver [sheath ?]) ? entry.sense: A. a) relative pron., may be used as the subj. or the dir. obj. of its clause: hān i ō man mat 1223; ēn fradand i andar aškamb dārēm 1013; has no cas. obl.; instead it takes an encl. pron. referring to the correlate: hān ... i-š āmōcišn he whose education 8017 (rare, commonly kē-š); cannot be governed by a prep.; instead the prep. is placed in the clause and governs a pron. referring to the correlate: *sīh-ē (v. 2sīh) ... i hac hān nēva-²kōktar būtan nē šāyist ‘splendor quo nullus pulchrior esse poterat’, a *splendour that was the most beautiful ever existent 717-18; or the prep. is changed into an adv. connected with the vb. of the clause: mēx i patiš bandēnd 300 xirs poles on which they fasten 300 *rings 2026 (bastan construed with pat; patiš the adv. of pat, v. s. v. patiš); in such cases kē is more usual. -- b) conj.: ēton ... i so ... that 2016-17. 3226-27; cand i as much as 3119; i ka, hān i ka, v. ka; -i-šān i, i-š i when, as soon as 5811. 6018 is possibly an imitation of Av. (1249) yaθa yat6. -- B. Iz2āfat. Relative clauses are often nominal without the copula, e. g. hān i hac tō kas he who is thy inferior 685; hān fradand i-š andar aškamb this child that is in her womb 123; hence the iz2āfat construction developed: by means of i, originally the subj. of a nominal clause without the copula, a subst., an adj., a prepositional attribute or an adv. is added to a subst. as its qualifier; I shall call these qualifiers relative attributes. A subst. added to a subst. in this way is the equivalent of our genitive, or it is in apposition. The relative attribute is 1. placed after its headw.: duxt i ēn varzēkar the [Page105-b] daughter of this farmer 1518-19; Frašāvart i tō pus 2310; pus i mas i Ardavān 318; vasān martōm i andar gēhān 418; vas xuāhišn i rāpak-karihā xuāhēt 7426-27; if more than one relative attribute is added the iz2āfat is repeated before each: 735 etc.; 2. paraphrased by hān i (ēn i, ēt i, ōi i) and placed before its headw.; this is the definite relative attribute: hān iZar-²tuxšt mātišt 3612; hān i tēžtom tāp 4322-23; etc.; -- forming possessives: a) placed after the headw.: i man my, i tō thy, i amāh our, i šmāh your, but in the 3d p. the encl. pron. is used: i-š his, her, i-šān their; b) placed before the headw. as a definite relative attribute: hān i man pusar 5121; ēt i tō humat 7315-16; hān i-š burtār 4323; hān i amāh dēh 5022-23; hān i ōi vēh-dēn 515, etc. -- forming the genitive of the interrog. kē: i kē ? hān i kē ? whose ?; other constructions with the iz2āfat, v. the demonstr. pronouns; -- after adverbs used as prepositions: pēš i, hacadar i, hacapar i, miyān i, etc., but the MSS are very little consistent in this respect. -- The limit between nominal relative clauses and relative attributes is sometimes floating. -- Av. (1199 sqq.) ya-; OP ya- rare, commonly hya- (haya- Strunk, KZ 81, 1967, 265 sqq., Eilers, ibd. 82, 1968, 62-68); Prth only in adverbs; MPrs ʾy, ʾyg, with encl. pron. ʾy-m, ʾy-š etc.; Paz. NP i, Paz. with encl. pron. y-am, y-at, y-aš, y-ašą. The spelling ʾy is wrongly taken as a proof of the pronunciation having been i; in fact it proves nothing, for in Syriac orthography a monosyllable i, whether i¤ or ī, could only be spelt y preceded by a glottal consonant. As to ʾyg, it represents in my opinion i-g < *i-ka = i-kāmak ‘whoever’, v. s. v. ka, no 5 (differently, not acceptable to me, Eilers, 1. c. 67, n. 2). -- The use of the iz2āfat is rather arbitrary in the BP written tradition. In order to facilitate the under- [Page106-a] standing I have added the iz2āfat in several passages where it would seem to be necessary, or at least possible. Unfortunately it has mistakenly crept into passages where it should not stand: it is to be cancelled in 1119 (better <u>). 4120-21 (read šʾtyhy instead of šʾtyh/y). 5116 (cancel both the iz2āfat and lʾd). 6521. 748. 935 (wanting in Dh.). 10623 (better <u>). -- 2019 read kōfē (cas. obl.) sar.

the animal spirit of man, as opposed to his ruvān and fravahr; common to human beings and animals 9717-18; perishable: death signifies kanišn i ~ u višōpišn i tan the destruction of the animal spirit and the disintegration of the body 6410-11; after death ~ merges with the Wind, and at the Resurrection Ohurmazd ... ~ hac vāt xuāhēt O. will claim the animal spirit back from the Wind 10012-13; tan u ~ u hīr u xuāstak 418. 1123; -- hence (physical) life, man's earthly life, passim; dagr zīvandakēh i ~ long life 5917; pat ~ i ... sōkand xuartan to swear an oath by the life of ... 21-23, passim, ~ apispārtan to give one's life (rād for a p.) 1110; ~ -apispār devoted 7011 (pat to); pat ~ i ... kōxšītan to [Page106-b] attempt a p.'s life 105-8; vas kōxšišn i ~ hard struggle for one's own life 7427. -- MPrthPrs gyʾn; KZŠPrth 1. 4 gyʾn Gr. v. ; < *vyāna-, cf Av. (1478) vyānā-; Paz. jąn, NP jān.

designed for the soul, *place of the soul of a deceased, a sepulchre: Sugud, i haft ~ andar būt, api-š haft-jānakānēh ēt kū haft xuatāidān andar būt Sogdiana, in which seven “soul-places” existed; and its possession of “seven soul-places” is explained by the fact that seven royal tombs (v. s. v. xuatāidān) existed there 11313-14: those of Yam, of Frētōn, of Manūcihr, of Kāyōs of Kai-Xōsrōi, of Luhrāsp, and of King Vištāsp (11. 15-17; Aži Dahāk is a spurious addition). -- The reading ḤYʾ-k6ʾn-handed down by such a careful and competent scribe as Mihrāpān should never have been doubted; Jamasp Asana's “emendations” haft (hwtʾdʾn =) xuatāyān, haft (hwtʾdʾnyh =) xuatāyānēh (a horrid form !) are sheer corruptions. Mihrāpān must be taken seriously. Certainly the idea of a place for the jān is absolutely contrary to the Iranian way of thinking, [Page107-a] but we are here in a part of Iran where Greeks reigned for about 200 years after Alexander (v. Tarn, The Greeks in Bactria & India, 1951). There is every reason to believe that their kings and magnates erected monumental buildings over their tombs, with which the of the deceased was in some way connected. The Greek could, however, only be rendered in Iranian by jān, as the ruvān belonged to a quite different sphere. Probably these seven jānakāns were built in the seven cities which Alexander founded in Bactriana and Sogdiana (Justin XII, 5, 8). The later attribution of such ancient monuments to the primordial heroes of East Iranian antiquity is a phenomenon too well known to need comment, cf Taxt i Jamšīd, Naqš i Rustam and the like. -- Strictly speaking the reading ḤYʾ-dʾnˡ = jān-dān ‘recaptacle of the jānʾ would be admissible (cf of the cinerary urn Sophocles, Electra 1126-1127), but this interpretation is perhaps too hazardous. -- jānakān has a parallel in MPrs rwʾngʾn, MPrth ʾrwʾngʾn ‘belonging to, serving the ruvān’, of pious works.
v. s. v. jān.

the act of slaying 1018 (correct initial g- to y- with one dot below). -- The NW form of zanišn, v. zatan. The passage is not quite clear. The text of the MSS: MNW-šʾnˡ ynšnˡ MN-šʾnˡ = kē-šān janišn hac-išān is ambiguous: ‘those from whom slaughter had arisen’ ? (but haciš would have been the correct construction), ‘those of them (hac-išān partitive, seems rather superfluous) by whom slaughter is done’ ? My emendation MRKʾ-ʾnˡ = MLKʾ-ʾnˡ = šāhān: ‘those kings from whom slaughter had arisen’ implies the difficulty that MRKʾ for MLKʾ is so far only attested in the inscriptions, and only in royal titles. Cf, on the other hand, BdA p. 22413-16: ōišān kē-šān xuat-*āyēn [for -āivēn ?] dāmēh rād [Page107-b] kart ēstēt, cigōn Dahāk u Frāsyāp u Vāman [thus Cod. DH; TD wʾtnˡ, Paz. vātan, perhaps for Vāδarjā the father of Vāman, Ṭab. I, 530 init.] u apārīk hac ēn āivēnak marg-aržānān, pātifrās [+ Paz. vama, probably a misspelt Vāman] 10 āivēnak-ic vitārēnd ‘those who have instituted their own *laws for mankind, as D. and F. and V. and other death deserving men of that kind, will undergo ten sorts of punishment’. For the whole passage cf Phl Vd ad 752 (p. 279).

jah- [yh-] to jump, to leap, 1. in the proper sense 3218: hān i hac pād i man bē jast that which jumped up from my foot, explained by the following har cē-š patkōft all that was hit by it. -- 2. fig. to arise, to happen 1211. 6911. 1127. -- Paz. NP jastan jah-.

, 7012 jahišn [yhšnˡ] Fortune, luck, dispensation 221. 1415; ~ u zamān <i> brihēnišn rād 1412, v. zamān; murvāk ~ i nēvak augury (and) good Fortune (i. e., good Fortune revealed through augury) 181; pat nēvak ~ <u> yazdān hayyārēh with good fortune and the help of the gods 1213-4; 1219; pat ~ hayyārēh i pat martōmān xrat vēh Fortune (giving aid to =) favouring men, wisdom is the best thing [she gives] 7012-13, Skr. v. siddheḥ sahāyatāyai manuṣyānām buddhiḥ uttamā; cf kē [for ka] ~ hayyār pat martōmān ciš i xrat vēh when Fortune (is a helper to =) favours men, wisdom is the best of things PT 675-6, with the explanation cē hakar parkast xuāstak bē šavēt aivāp cahārpād bē mīrēt xrat bē mānēt for if wealth dwindles and is lost or animals die wisdom remains; pātixšāi hān nēvaktar i ... xrat u dānišn nēvak api-š ~ hayyārēh apāk that ruler [Page108-a] is best who is of good wisdom and knowledge and with whom is the help of Fortune GF III, 94. -- Paz. jahišn, zahišn (ad 7012), Skr. v. siddhi. There is a certain confusion in the MSS between dahišn and jahišn (jāyišn), but the reading with j- is the only admissible one in the sense given here (against West, Tavadia, Pagliaro). -- The etymology is obscure. The two parallel forms seem to represent *jā¤yišn, of which *jayišn developed to jahišn according to the common rule. The vb. seems to be a lw. from NW with an original j- (ž-) which changed to z in SW: Paz. zahišn; cf jamān: zamān. Cf Bailey, ZP 82 n. 5. [Page108-a]
